div.l: (base) Lat se now / of youre wommanly pitee
(base) He is / a kynges brother sone pardee
(base) And thogh he were / a poure Bachiler
(base) Syn he hath serued yow / so many a yeer
(base) And had for yow / so greet aduersitee
(base) It moste been considred / leueth me
(base) For gentil mercy / oghte to passen right
(base) ¶ Thanne seyde he thus / to Palamon the knyght
(base) I trowe / ther nedeth litel sermonyng
(base) To make yow / assente to this thyng
(base) Com neer / and taketh youre lady by the hond
(base) Bitwixe hem / was maad anon the bond
(base) That highte matrymoigne / or mariage
(base) By al the conseil / and the Baronage
(base) And thus / with alle blisse / and melodye
(base) Hath Palamon / ywedded Emelye
(base) And god / that al this world hath wroght
(base) Sende hym his loue / that hath it deere aboght
(base) For now is Palamon / in alle wele
(base) Lyuynge in blisse / in richesse / and in heele
(base) And Emelye / hym loueth so tendrely
(base) And he / hir serueth so gentilly
(base) That was ther no word hem bitwene
(base) Of Ialousie / or any oother teene
(base) Thus endeth Palamon / and Emelye
(base) And god saue / al this faire compaignye Amen
(base) ¶ Here is ended / the knyghtes tale

Here endeth the knyghtis tale /And here begyn
neth the ꝓprolog of the Miller
WHan that þe knyght had þus his tale tolde
In all the cōmpany ne was þꝰere yong ne olde
That he ne said it was a noble storye
And worthy to be taken in memorye
And nameliche the gentilles euꝰeryche one
Our oste lough and swor so mote I gone
This goth a right on bokeled is the male
Lete se now who shall telle an other tale
For truly the game is weel by gonne
Now telle ye ꝸ monk if that ye conne
Somwhat to acquyte with þe knyghtes tale
The myller that dronken was and pale
So that vnnethes vpon his hors he satte
He wold avale nouther hood ner hatte
Ne abyde any man for his curtesye
But in Pilates voys he gan to crye
And swoor by armes blood and bones
I can a noble tale for the nones
Wtith whiche I wole now quyte the knyghtes tale
Oure oste saw þat he was dronken of ale
And seide abyde Robyn lyef brother
Som better man shall telle vs first an other
And abyde and lete vs werke thriftely
By goddes soule qd he þat wole nat I
For I wole speke or elles go my weye
Oure oste answered sey on a deuyl weye
Thow art a fole þin witte is ouꝰere comen
Now herkeneth qd the myller alle and som
But first I make a ꝓprotestacioūn
That I am dronke I knowe it by the sown
And therfore if I mysspeke or seye
Wite weel the ale of southwerk I you preye
For I wole telle a legende and a lyfe
Bothe of a Carpenter and his wyfe
How a Clerk farced the wrightes cappe
The Reve answered and seid stynte thy clappe
Lete be thy lewde dronken harlotrye
It is a synne and eke grete folye
To appeyren any man or hym diffame
And eke to bryng wyves in suche name
Thow maist y now of other thyngges seyne
This dronken myller answered sone a geyne
And seid lyef brother Oswalde
Who hath no wyfe he is no Cukkolde
But I sey nat therfore that thow art none
There be full gode wyves many one
Why art thou angry wtith my tale now
I haue a wyfe perde as weel asthow
Yet nold I for the oxone in my plough
Take vpon me more thanne I nowgh
As demen of my self þat I were one
I wole byleve that I am none
An husbond shall nat be inquisityf
Of goddes pryuyte ne of his wyf
So he may fynde goddis foysen there
Of the remenant nedeth nat to inquire
What I shuld I more seye but the Millerꝰer
He nold his woordes for no man forbere
But tolde his cherles tale in this manerꝰer
Me forthynketh þat I shal reherse it herꝰer
And therfore euꝰery gentill wight I preye
Demeth nat for goddes loue þat I seye
Of euell entente but for I mote reherce
Here tales alle be they better werse
Or elles falsen som of my matierꝰer
And therforꝰer who so lust it nat herꝰer
Torne ouꝰere the leef and chese an other tale
For ye shall fynde y nowe bothe grete and smale
Of historiall thyng that toucheth gentilnesse
And eke moralite and holynesse
Blame nat me if þat ye chese a mys
Þe myller is a Cherle ye knowe weel this
So was þe Reue eke and other moo
And harlotrye they tolde eke bothe twoo
Aduyse you and put me out of blame
And eke men shal nat make ernest of game
Here endeth the ꝓprologe and begynneth the Tale as here folweth
Here endeth the ꝓprologe and begynneth the Tale as here folweth
WHilom þꝰere was duellyng in Oxenforth
A riche gnoffe and gestes hield to boorde
And of his crafte he was a Carpente
With hym ther was duellyng a pore scoler
Had lerned arte but all hise fantasye
Was torned to lerne astrologye
And coude certeyn of conclusions
To demen by interrogacions
Yf that men axed hym in certeyn houres
What Whan þat men shuld haue drought or shoures
And if men axed hym what shuld befalle
Of euꝰery thyng I may nat rekne alle
This Clerke was cleped hende Nicholas
Of derne love and preuy solas
And therto he was sligh and full pryue
And like to a maide meke for to see
A Chambre had he in that ostelrye
All lone with out any companye
Full fetisly dight with herbes swote
And he hym self as swote as is þe rote
Of licoryce or any situale
His almagiste and bokes grete and smale
His Astrelabre longyng for his arte
His awgryme stones lay full faire a parte
On shelues couched at his beddes heed
His presse y couꝰered with a faldyng reed
And al a bove ther lay a gay sawtry
On the whiche on þe nyght he made melody
So swotely that all the chaumbre y rongge
And Angelus ad virginem he songge
And after þat he song the kyngges note
Full often blyssed was hise mery throte
And thus this swete Clerk hise tyme spente
After hise frendes fyndyng and hise rente
This Carpente had wedded newly a wyfe
Whiche that he loued more thanne his lyfe
Of xviij yeer she was of age
Ielous he was and kept hir streyt in cage
For she was wylde and yong and he was olde
And demed hym self to ben a Cukewolde
He knewe nat Catou for hise wit was rude
That bad men shuld wedde ther similitude
Men shuld wedden after ther estate
For youthe and elde is often at debate
But sythen he was fallen in the snare
He must enduren as other folk his care
Faire was þis yong wyf and þꝰere with all
As eny vessell hir body gente and small
A seynt she wered barred all of sylk
A barme cloth as white as morne mylk
Vpon hir lyendes full of many a goore
White was s hir smok and enbrowded all by fore
And eke be hynde of hir coler a boute
Of Coleblak sylk with ynne and eke with oute
The Tapes of hir white voluper
Wer of þe same sute of hir coler
Hir fyllet brode of sylk and sette full high
And sikerly she had a lycorous eye
Full small y pulled wer hir browes twoo
And tho euꝰere bente and blak as eny sloo

Speke swete brydde I ne wote where thow arte
This Nicholas a none lete flye a farte
As grete as it had be a thundre dente
That with the strook he was all moost y blente
And he was redy with hise yron hote
And Nicholas in the ars he smote

The hote cultre brenned so his toute
And for þe smerte he wened for to deye
As he were wode for woo he gan to crye
Helpe water water helpe for goddes herte
This Carpenter out of his slombre sterte
And herde one crye water as he were wode
And thought allas Noyes Flode
And sette hym with woordes moo
And with an ax smette the corde a twoo
And doun goth all he fonde neyther to selle
Bꝰerred ner ale till he come to the selle
Vpon the floor and theron swowned he lay
Vp sterte hir Alisou and Nicholay
And cryed out me harrowe in the strete
The neybous bothe smale and grete
In ronne for to gawren on this man
That a swowne lay bothe pale and wan
For wtith þat fal he hath y broken his arme
But standen he must vn to his owen harme
For whan he spake he was a none borne doun
With hende Nicholas and Alisoūn
They tolde euꝰery man þat he was wode
He was so a gaste of Noyes Flode
Thurgh fantasye þat of his vanite
He had y bought hym knedynge tubbes three
And had hem hanged in the roof a boven
And þat he parayed hem for goddes love
To sytten in the roof pur companye
The folke gan lawghen at his fantasye
And to the roof they keken and they gape
And torned all his harme into a Iape
For what so euꝰere this Carpentꝰere answerde
It was for nought no man his reson herde
With othes grete he was so sworne a doun
That he was holden wode in all þat toun
For euꝰery Clerk a none right helde with other
They seid this man is wode my lief brother
And euꝰery wight gan laghen at hise stryfe
Thus swyved was þe Carpentꝰers wyfe
For all hise kepyng and his ielosye
And Absalou hath kyssed hir nether eye
And Nicholas is scalded in his toute
This tale is done and god saue all þe route
Here endethh the Tale of the Miller

¶ The prologe of the Cookes tale
The Cook / of Londoun / whil the Reue spak
For ioye hym thoughte / he clawed hym on the bak
Haha quod he / for Cristes passioun
This Millere / hadde a sharpe conclusioun
Vp on his argument of herbergage
Wel seyde Salomon / in his langage
Ne bryng nat euery man / in to thyn hous
For herberwyng by nyghte is perilous
Wel oghte a man / auysed for to be
Whom that he broghte / in to his priuetee
I pray to god / so yeue me sorwe and care
If euer sith / I highte hogge of ware
Herde I a Millere / bettre yset awerk
He hadde a iape of malice / in the derk
But god forbede / that we stynten heere hic
For if ye / vouche sauf to heere audire
A tale of me / that am a poure man
I wol yow telle / as wel as euere I kan
A litel iape / that fil in oure Citee
¶ Oure hoost answerde / and seyde I graunte it thee
Now tel on Roger / looke that it be good
For many a pastee / hastow laten blood
And many a Iakke of Douere / hastow soold
That hath been twies hoot and twies coold
Of many a pilgrym / hastow Cristes curs
For of thy presle / yet they fare the wors
That they han eten / with thy stubbul goos
For in thy shoppe / is many a flye loos
Now tel on / gentil Roger / by thy name
But yet I praye thee / be nat wrooth for game
A man may seye ful sooth / in game and pley
¶ Thow seist ful sooth / quod Roger by my fey
But sooth pley quade pley / as the Flemyng seith
And therfore herry Bailly / by thy feith
Be thou nat wrooth / er we departen heer
Thogh that my tale / be of an hostiler
But nathelees / I wol nat telle it yit
But er we parte / ywis thow shalt be quyt
And ther with al / he lough / and made cheere
And seyde his tale / as ye shal after heere
Here endeth the prologe .
¶ Here bigynneth the Cook his tale
Narrat
A Prentis / whilom dwelled in oure Citee
And of a craft of vitaillers was he
Gaillard he was / as goldfynch in the shawe
Broun as a berye / a propre short felawe
With lokkes blake / ykembd ful fetisly
Dauncen he koude / so wel and iolily
That he / was clepyd Perkyn Reuelour
He was / as ful / of loue and paramour
As is the hyue / ful of hony swete
Wel was the wenche / that with hym myghte meete
At euery bridale / wolde he synge and hoppe
He loued bet the Tauerne / than the shoppe
For / whan ther any ridyng was in Chepe
Out of the shoppe / thider wolde he lepe
Til that he hadde / al the sighte yseyn
And daunced wel / he wolde noght come ageyn
And gadred hym / a meynee of his sort
To hoppe and synge / and maken swich disport
And ther / they setten steuene / for to meete
To pleyen at the dees / in swich a Streete
For in the town / nas ther no Prentys
That fairer / koude caste a paire of dys
Than Perkyn koude / and ther to he was free
Of his dispense / in place of pryuetee
With Magot ⁊ with Mylsent whan þat he mette
The bagge with þe powder anon was vnknette
His purs was inperfit he couthe notwelle kepe
Yet let vs be mery while oure sire is aslepe
With Pyes ⁊ with Pykrels with wyues moste swete
With loche ⁊ with lamprey þe childe myght not ete
The Tapster þe Taverner þe koke was nedy
Wolde clepe on perkyn for his purs was so redy
That foond his maister wel / in his chaffare
For ofte tyme / he foond his box ful bare
For euery other day his boxe was lefte bare
For sikerly / a prentys reuelour
An vnthrysty begynnyng for yong or for olde
That haunteth dees / ryot or paramour
A Prentyse to be a reueloure ⁊ ꝑperamours to holde
His maister / shal it in his shoppe abye
That bargeyn no man so sore schalle Abye
Al haue he / no part of the Minstralcye
For thefte and riot / they been couertible
Al konne he pleye / on Giterne / or Rubible
Reuel and trouthe / as in a lowe degree
They been ful wrothe al day / as men may see
When þy purs is penyles where schalt þou haue more
Thou þat wylt not þe ottupie no thyng therfore
Revel ys ordeyned to hem þat mow pay
But prentise ne pore man þey mowe not away
Euelle sponne wolle at the laste wolle come oute
They þou kepe it neuer so prevey in alytelle cloute
¶ This ioly Prentys / with his Maister bood
Til he were neigh / out of his prentishood
Al were he snybbed / bothe erly and late
And som tyme / lad with reuel to Newgate
Where he his vnthriftynes sore aboughte
But atte laste / his maister hym bithoghte
Vpon a day / whan he his papir soghte
To over se his papire ⁊ hym thorow sought
Of a prouerbe / that seith this same word
Wel bet is roten Appul / out of hoord
Than that it rotte / al the remenaunt
So fareth it by a riotous seruaunt
It is ful lasse harm / to lete hym pace
Than he shende / alle the seruantz in the place
Euen as a stabbed schepe in þe folde
Alle a flocke wolle defyle both yonge ⁊ olde
Ryght euen so a febel seruaunt may
Distruye fourty of his felaws in a day
Therfore / his maister gaf hym acquitaunce
And bad hym go / with sorw / and with meschaunce
Better ys betyme to voyde suche a clerke
The lenger he abydeth þe wors is his werke
He þat his Maister no profite wolle wynne
Y holde hym better out of þe hous þan with ynne
And thus this ioly prentys / hadde his leeue
Now lat hym riote / al the nyght or leeue
And for ther nys no theef withoute a lowke
That helpeth hym / to wasten and to sowke
Of that he brybe kan / or borwe may
Anon / he sente his bed / and his array
Vnto a compeer / of his owene sort
That loued dees / and reuel / and disport
And hadde a wyf / that heeld for contenaunce
A shoppe / and swyued for hir sustenaunce
¶ Here endith the Cokys tale
// Incipit Fabula /

Here begynneth the Shipmannes tale
A Marchaunt whilom duelled at seynt denys
That riche was for whiche men helde hym wys
A wife he had of excellente beaute
And compayngnable and reuerent was she
Whiche is a thyng þat causeth more expens
Þat worth is al þe chier and reuꝰerence
That men done at festis or daunces
Suche salutacoūns or countenaūnnces
Passeth as dooth þe shadowe vpon þe wal
But woo is hym þat paye shall for all
The sely husbond algate he must paye
He must vs clothe he must vs arraye
All for his owen worship richely
In whiche array we daunce Iolily
And if þat he may nat ꝑper auentre
Or elles no suche despences endure
But thynketh it is a waste and y loste
Þanne mote a nother paye for oure coste
Or lende vs gold and þat is perelous
Þis noble marchaūnt hilde a noble hous
For whiche he hadde all daye grete repaire
For his largenesse and for his wife was faire
That wondre is but herkenes to my tale
A mong alle guestes grete and smale
There was a monke a faire man and a bolde
I trowe XXXtiri wynter he was olde
Þat euꝰere was drawyng to þat place
This yong monke þat was so faire of face
And quaynted was soo þat þis good man
Sithe þat he first hise knowlege by gan
Þat in his hous as famyliar was he
As it is possible eny frende for to be
And for as moche as this gode man
And eke þis Monke of whiche þat I began
Were bothe two y borne in one village
The monke hym claymeth as for Cosynage
And he a yen he saith nat ones naye
But was als glad ther of as foule of daye
For to his herte it was a grete plesaūnnce
Thus be they knytte with etꝰerne alliaūnce
And ilke of hem gan other to assure
Of brotherhode whiles þer lyves may endure
Free was daun Iohn and manly of dispence
As in þat hous and eke full of diligence
To doo plesaūnnce and also grete Costage
He not foryate to geve the liest page
In all þat hous but after ther degree
He yaf the lord and after alle the menee
Whanne þat he cam som maner honeste thyng
For whiche þei were as glad of his comyng
As foule is fayne whanne sonne vp riseth
Nomore of þis for now it sufficeth
But so byfele þat þis Marchaunt vp on a daye
Shope hym to make hym redy in arraye
To warde þe toun of Bruges for to fare
To byen hym there a porcoūn of good ware
For whiche he hath to Parissh sent a noone
A Massenger and praied hath daun Iohn
Þat he shuld come to seynt Denys and playe
With hym and wtith his wife a daye or twaye
Er he to Bruges wente in any wise
This noble Monke of whiche I you devise
Hath of his Abbot as hym luste licence
By cause he was a man of high prudence
And eke an Officer out for to ride
To see her graunges and eke her biernes wide
And vn to seynt denys he cometh a noone
He was welcome as my lord daun Iohn
O dere Cosyn full of Curtesie
With hym brought a Iugge of maluesye
And eke an other full of fyne vernage
And volatile as ay was his vsage
And þus I lete hem ete and drynke and play
This Marchaūnt and þis Monke a day or tway
The thridde day this Marchaūnnt vp he ryseth
And on his nedys hym sadly aviseth
And vp in to his Countre hous goth he
To rekne with hym self as weel may be
Of thilke yeer how þat it with hym stode
And how þat he dispended hath his good
And if þat he encresed were or noone
His bokes and his bagges many one
He leith by forne hym on his countyng boorde
For riche was his tresore and his hoorde
For whiche full faste his countre dore he shette
And loked þat no man shulde hym lette
Of his accomptes for the meane tyme
And þus he sat til it was passed pryme
Daun Iohn was rysen in þe morwe also
And in þe garden walketh to and fro
And hath his thyngges saide full curteislye
This good wife cam walkyng full pryuelye
In to the gardeyn there he walketh softe
And hym salueth as she hath done ofte
A maide Childe come in hir companye
Whiche as hir luste may gouꝰerne and guye
For yet vnder þe yarde was þe maide
O dere Cosyn myne Daun Iohn she saide
What ailes yow so rathe for to ryse
Nece qd he it aught y now to suffise
Fyve houres for to slepe on nyght
But it were for an h olde palled wight
As ben þese wedded men þat ly and dare
As in a forme sitteth a wery hare
Þat wer all for straugth wtith houndes grete and smale
But dere Nece why be ye so pale
I trowe Certes þat oure gode man
Hath you labored sith þe nyght by gan
Þat you were nede to resten hastely
And wtith þat woord he lough full merily
And of his owne þought he wax all reed
Þis faire wife gan to shake hir heed
And saide þus god wote all qd she
Nay Cosyn myne it standeth nat soo wtith me
For by þat god þtat gaf soule and lyfe
In all þe Realme of Fraūnce is þer no wife
Þat lesse luste hath to þat sory play
For I may syng allas and weel a way
Þat I was borne but no wight qd she
Dar I nat telle how it stante with me
Wherfore I thynke out of þis londe to wende
Or elles of my self to make an ende
So full am I of drede and eke of care
This Monke by gan vp on þis wife to stare
And saide Allas my Nece god forbede
Þat ye for any sorwe or for drede
For do your self but telleth me yorur greef
ꝐPer auentre I may in youre myschief
Counsel or helpe and þerfore telleth me
All your a noye for it shal be secree
For on my portoos I make an othe
Þat neuer in lyve for lief nor lothe
Ne shal I of no counsell you by wraye
Þe same a yen to you qd she I saye
By god and by þis portoos I swere
Þough men me wolde al in to pecis tere
Ne shal I neuꝰere for to goo to helle
By wreye woord of þing men me telle
Nat for no Cosynage ne for none alliaūnnce
But verely for love and affiaūnnce
Thus be thei sworne and here vp on kissed
And ilke of hem tolde other what hem lyste
Cosyn qd she if I hadde a space
As I haue noon and namely in this place
Thenne wolde I telle a legende of my lyfe
What I haue suffred sithe I was wyfe
With myne husbond all þough he be yorur Cosyn
Nay qd þis Monke by god and by seynt Martyn
He is no more Cosyn vn to me
Þanne is þe leef þat hanggeth on þe tree
I clepe hym soo by seynt Denys in Fraūnnce
To haue þe more cause of acqueyntaūnnce
Of you whiche I haue loued specially
A bouen alle women sikerly
This swere I you on my ꝓprofessiou
Telleth youre greef lest þat he come doun
And hasteth you and goo your weye a noone
My dere love qd she O Daun Iohn
Full lief me were þis Counsel to hyde
But oute it mote it may no longger a byde
Myne husbond is to me þe werste man
Þat euer was sithe þe worlde by gan
But sith I am a wife it sitte nat me
To telle no wight of oure preuyte
Neither in bed ne in noone other place
God shelde I shuld telle it for his grace
A wife shuld nat seye of hir husbond
But all honour as I can vnderstonde
Saf vn to you þus moche telle I shal
As helpe me god he is nat worth at all
In no degre þe value of a flye
But yet me greueth moost his nyggardye
And weel ye wote þat women naturaly
Desiren suche thyngges as weel as I
Thei wold þat her husbondes shuld be
Hardy and wise riche and eke Free
And buxom to his wife and fressh in bedde
But by þat lord þat for vs blode bledde
For his honour my self to arraye
A sonday nexte me must paye
An hundred frankes or elles I am lorne
Yet were me leuer þat I were on borne
Þanne me were doone a slaundre or a vilanye
I ne were but loste and þerfore I you preye
Liende me þis sōmme or elles me must deye
Daun Iohn I seye liende me þese hundred frankes
Pardee wole I nat faile you my thankes þankes
If þat you luste to do þat I praye
For at a certeyn daye I wole you paye
And do you what plesaūnnce and ꝸuice
Þat I may do right as you lust deuyse
And but I do god on me take vengeaūnce
As foule as had geneuylion of Fraūnnce
This gentil monke answered in þis maner
Now truly myne owen lady dere
I haue on you so grete a ruthe
Þat I swere to you and plight my truthe
Þat whenne youre husbond is to flaundres fare
I wole delyuꝰere you out of all þis care
For I wole bryng you an hundred frankes
And wtith þat he caught hir by þe flankes
And hir enbraced harde and kissed hir ofte
Goth now your weye qd he all stille and softe
And lete vs dyne as sone as ye may
For by kalendre it is pryme on þe daye
Goth now and be as true as I shal be
Now elles god forbede ꝸ qd she
And forth she goth as iolyfe as a pye
And bad þe Cokes þtat þei shuld hem hye
So þat men myght dyne and þat a noone
Vn to hir husbond is þis wife goon
And knokketh at his countre boldely
Quy la. qd he petre it am I
Qd she what how long wha wole ye faste
How long tyme wole ye rekne and caste
Youre somes youre bokes and youre þingges
The deuel haue parte of alle suche rekenyngges
Ye haue y nough pardee of goddes sonde
Come to daye and lete youre bagges hong
Ne be ye nat a shamed þat daun Iohn
Shall fastyng all þis daye þus elongely goone
Lete vs here masse and goo we dyne
Wife qd þis man litel canst þu deuyne
The curious besynesse þat we haue
For of vs Chapmen so god me saue
And by þat lord þat cleped is seynt yve
Scarsely a mong xij two shul thryve
Contynually lastyng vn to oure age
We may weel make a gode visage
And dryve forth þe worlde as it may be
And kepe oure estate in preuyte
Till we be deede or elles þat we play
A pilgrymage or gone out of þe way
And þerfore haue I grete necessite
Vp on þis queynte worlde to aduyse me
For euer more we mote stonde in drede
Of happe and fortune in oure chapmanhede
To Flaundres wole I goo to morwe at daye
And come a gayn als sone as I maye
For whiche my dere wife I þe beseke
As be to euꝰery wight buxom and meke
And for to kepe oure good be Curious
And honestly gouꝰerne weel oure hous
Þou haf hast y nough in euꝰery maner wise
Þat to a trusty wife may suffise
The lakketh none array ne none vitaile
Of syluer in thy purs þou maist nat faile
And wtith þat woord his Countre dore he on shette
And doun he goth no longger wolde he lette
But hastely a masse was there saide
And spedely þe tables were y laide
And to þe dyner fast þei hem spedde
And richely þe Chapman þe monke fedde
And after dyner daun Iohn sobrely
This Chapman toke a parte preuyly
And saide hym Cosyn þus it standeth soo
Þat weel I see to Bruges wole ye goo
God and seynt Austyn spede you and guyde
I pray you Cosyn wisely þat ye ride
Gouꝰerne you also of youre diete
Attemꝑperly and namely in þis hete
By twen vs twoo nedeth no straunge fare
Fare weel Cosyn God shilde you fro Care
If any thyng be there by day or by nyght
If it lay in my power or in my myght
Þat ye wole comaunde me done in any wise
It shall be done right as ye wole deuyse
O þing er þat ye goone if it may be
I wolde praye you for to lende me
An hundred frankes a daye or tweye
For certeyn bestis þat I must beye
To store with a place þat is oures
God helpe me soo it I wolde it were youres
I shal nat faile suerly at my daye
Nought for a Ml frankes a myle waye
But lete þis thyng be secrete I you praye
For þese bestis þis nyght yet must I paye
And fare now weel my Cosyn dere
Graunt mcy of your coste and of your chere
This noble Marchaunt gently a noone
Answered and saide O Cosyn daun Iohn
Now sekerly is þis a smal requeste
My golde is youre owen when you leste
And nat onely my gold but my chaffare
Take what you luste god shield ye spare
But one thyng as ye knowe it weel y nough
Of Chapmen þat her money is her plough
We may creaunce whiles we haue a name
But goldeles for to be it is no game
Pay it a geyn when it lithe in youre ease
Afor my myght ful fayn wolde I you plese
These C frankes he fette forth a noone
And pryuely he to toke hem to Daun Iohn
Noo wight in all þis worlde wist of þis loone
Sauyng þis Marchaunt and daun Iohn allone
They drynke and spake and ronne a while and play
Till þat daun Iohn rideth vn to his abbaye
The morwe cam and forth þis Marchaunt rideth
To Flaundres warde his appntice wel hym guydeth
Til he come to Bruges murely
Now goth þis Marchaūnnt fast and besily
A boute his nede and beyeth and creaunseth
He nouther pleyeth at þe dyce ne daunseth
But as a marchaunt shortely for to telle
He badde his lyfe and þere I late hym duelle
The sonday next Daun Iohn is goon
To seynt Denys he is come a noon
With Croune and berde all fressh and newe y shave
In all þe house þer nas so litel a knave
Ne no wight elles þtat he ne was full fayn
For þtat my lord daun Iohn was come a gayn
And shortely to her poynte for to goone
This faire wife accordeth with daun Iohn
Þat for þese C frankes he shuld all nyght
Haue hir in hise armes bolte vp right
And þis accorde ꝑperformed was in dede
In myrthe all nyght a besy lyfe thei lede
Til it was daye þat daun Iohn went his waye
And bad þe meny fare wel and haue good daye
For none of hem ne no wight in þe toun
Hath of daun Iohn right non suspeccou
And forth he rideth hom till his Abbeye
Or where hym luste no more of hym I seye
Þis Marchaunt when þtat ended was þe feyre
To seynt Denys he gan to repaire
And wtith his wife he maketh feste and chier
And telleth þat Chaffare is soo dere
Þat nedes must he make a chevesaunce
For he was y bounde in a recognisaunce
To paye XXti thousand shieldes a noon
For whiche þis Marchaunt is to paryssh goon
To borwe of certeyn frendes þat he hadde
A Certeyn Frankes and some wtith hym he ladde
And whanne he was come to þe toun
For grete chier and grete affeccioūn
Vn to daun Iohn he first goth hym to playe
Nought for to borwe of hym no monaye
And for to wete and see of his welfare
And for to telle hym of his Chaffare
As frendes done whan þei be met in fere
Daun Iohn hym maketh feste mid mery chere
And he hym tolde a gayn full specially
How he had bought full weel and garaciously
Thanked be god his marchaundize
Sauf þat he must in all maner wise
Make a chevesaunce as for his beste
And þanne he shulde be in ioye and reste
Daun Iohn answered Certes I am fayn
Þat ye in hele arn comen a gayn
And if þat I were riche as haue I blisse
Of xxtiri thousand shieldes shuld ye nat mysse
For ye so kyndely this other daye
Lente me gold and as I can and may
I thanke you by god and by seynt Iame
But natheles I toke it to oure dame
Your wife at home þe same gold a gayn
By certeyn tokens she wote it weel certayn
Vp on your benche þat I can hir telle
Now by your leve I may no lengger duelle
Oure Abbot wele out of þis toun a noone
And in hise compaygnye must I goone
Grete weel oure dame my nees swete
And fare weel my Cosyn til þtat we mete
Þis Marchaūnt whiche þtat was bothe ware and wise
Creaunced hath and payed eke at parish
To certeyn lumbardes and payed redy in honde
This some of gold and toke of hem his bonde
And home he goth as mery as a popyn Iaye
For weel he knewe he stode in suche arraye
That nedes must he wynne in suche a viage
A Ml frankes by side all his Costage
His wife full redy mette hym at þe gate
As she was wonte of vsage algate
And all þat nyght in merthe þei be sette
For he was riche and clerly out of dette
Whanne it was daye þis Marchaūnt gan ēmbrace
His wife all newe and kissed hir on þe face
And vp he goth and maketh it full tough
Nomore qd she by god ye haue y nough
And wantounely wtith hym she pleyed
Till at þe last þis Marchaunt seide
By god qd he I am a litel wroth
Wtith you my wife all though it be me looth
And wote ye why by god as þat I guesse
Þat ye haue made a maner straungenesse
By twen me and my Cosyn Daun Iohn
Ye shuld haue warned me er I had goon
Þat he you hadde an C frankes y payed
For as me semed he was nat weel y payed
For þat I spake to hym of chevisaunse
Me semed so by hise countenaunce
But nertheles by god heuene kyng
I thought nat to axe hym no thyng
I praye you wife do ye no more soo
Telle me all wey er þtat I fro you goo
Yf any dettorurs haue in myne absence
Y payed to þe aught / for þurgh thyne necligence
I may hym axe a thyng þat is payed
She was nat a ferde ne affrayed
But holly she saide and þat a noone
Mary I defye þat Munke daun Iohn
I kepe nat of his tokenes neuer a deel
He toke me certeyn gold þtat wote I weel
Þat euel deth vpon his monkes snowte
For god it wote I wende wtith oute doute
Þat he had goven it me by cause of yow
To do þꝰer with myne owen ease and myne prow
For Cosynage and eke for beal chier
Þat he hath hadde full ofte tymes here
But sith I stonde in his disioynte
I wole you answere shortely to þe poynte
Sh / ye haue more slakke dettorurs þanne I
For I wole paye you weel and redely
Fro daye to daye and if so be y faile
I am your wife / score it on my taile
And I shal paye it as soone as I may
For by myne trouth I haue on myne array
And nat in waste by stowed it euꝰery deel
And for I haue stowed it so weel
To youre honour / For goddes sake I say
As beth nat wroth but lete vs laugh and play
Ye shall my Ioly body haue to wedde
By god I nyl nought paye you but in bedde
Foryeve it me myne owen spouse dere
Torne hederwarde and make better chere
Þis Marchaūnt þtat þer nas no better remedie
And for to chide it ne were but folye
Sith þtat þe þing may nat amended be
Now wife he saide þanne I foryeve it the
But by thy lyfe be no moore so large
Kepe better my good this gif I the in charge
Thus endeth now my tale and god vs sende
Talkyng y nowgh vn to oure lyves ende
Here endeth the tale of the Maryn
Here begynneth the tale prolog of the Pirierasses ta
WEle y saide by Corps dūns qd oure hooste
Now long mote þou saile by þe cooste
Sir gentle Maister gentil Marynere
God yeve þe Monke a Ml laste of quadeyere
A ha felawes by ware of suche a Iape
Þe Monke put in þe Mannes hode an ape
And his wives eke by seynt Austyn
Drawes noo Munkes moore to youre ynne
But now passe ouer and lete seke a boute
Who shal now telle first of all þis Rowte
An other tale and wtith þat woorde he saide
As Curteysly as it hadde ben a mayde
My lady Prioresse by youre leve
So þat I wiste I shuld you nat greve
I wolde deme þat ye telle shulde
A tale nexte if so were þtat ye wolde
Now wole ye vouchesauf my lady dere
Glady qd she and seid in þis manere

l.hi: Here begynneth the priorasses tale ofAlma Redemptoris

div.l: O lord oure lord þi name how meruelous
Is in þis large worlde spradde qd she
For nought onely thy laude precious
ꝐPerformed is by men of Dignite
But by þe mouthe of Childre þi boūnnte
Performed is on oure breest sowkyng
Some tyme shewe they thyne heryng
Wherfore in laude as I best can or may
Of þe and of thy white lyly floure
Whiche þat þe bare and is a maide alway
To telle a storye I wole do my laboure
Nought þat encres I may your laboure
For she hir self is honour and Rote
Of bounte next hir sone and soules boote
O Moder maide O maide moder free
O bussh on brente brennyng in Moises sight
Þat Raueshediste doune fro the deite
Þurgh thy humblesse þe goste þat in þe light
Of whos vertue whenne he in thyne herte light
Conceyved was þe Fader sapience
Helpe me to telle it in thy Reuerence
Lady thy bounte thyne magnificence
Thy vertue and thy grete humylite
Ther may no tung expresse in noo science
For som tyme lady er men praye to the
Thou gooste by forne of thy benignite
And guetist vs the light of oure prayer
To geten vs to thy sone soo dere
My konyng is to weike o blisfull quene
For to declare thy grete worthynesse
Þat I ne may nat þe with susteyne
But as a Childe xij moneth olde or lesse
Þat can vnnethes any woord expresse
Right so fare I and therfore I you praye
Guideth my song þat I shal of you saye

l.hi: Here folweth the tale of the seid priorasseto a conclusion

div.l: There was in Asye in a grete Cite
A mong Cristen folke a Iurye
Susteyned by a lord of þat Contre
Suche maner doctryne as men vse there
For foule vsure and lucre of vilanye
Hatefull to Criste and to his companye
And þurgh þe strete ride or wende .
For it and open at euery
A litel scole of Cristen folke there stode
Doun at ferther ende in whiche there were
Children an heep / y come of Cristes bloode
Þat lerned in þat scole yere by yere
Suche maner doctryne as men vse there
This is to seye to syng and eke to rede
As smale Children done in her Childehede
A mong these Children was a widewes sone
A litel Clergion þat vij yeer was of age
That daye by daye to scole was his wone
And eke also where so he saugh þe ymage
Of Cristes moder / hadde he eke the vsage
As hym was taught to knele a doun and say
His Aue Maria as he goth by the waye
Thus hath þis widewe hir litel Childe y taught
Oure blisfull lady Cristes moder dere
To worship ay / he forgete it naught
For Sely Childe wolde alwey sone lere
But ay whenne I remembre of þis matere
Seynt Nicholas stante euer in my presence
For he to Criste so yong dide reuerence
This litel Childe his litel boke lernyng
As he sat in þe scole at his prymer
He Alma Redemptoris herde syng
As Children lerned her antiphoner
And as he durste he drough hym ner and nere
And herkened ay þe woordes and þe note
Till he þe firste verse coude all by Rote
Nat wiste he what þis latyn was to saye
For he was yong and tendre eke of age
But on a daye his felawe gan he praye
To expoune hym þis song in his langage
Or telle hym why þis song was in vsage
This preyed he hym to construe and declare
Full often tymes vp on his knees bare
His felawe whiche þat was older þanne he
Answered hym þus þis song I haue herde say
Was made for oure lady blisful lady free
Hir to salue and eke hir to praye
To ben oure helpe and oure socorur whanne we deye
I can no more expoune in this matier
I lere syngg I can no more gramer
And is this song made in reuꝰerence
Of Cristes moder seide this Innocente
Now Certes I wole do my diligence
To knowe it all er Cristemasse be wente
Though I for my premer shule be sente
And shuld be beten thries in an houre
I wole it konne oure lady to honoure
His felawe taught hym homward pryuyely
Fro daye to daye til he coude it by Rote
And þanne he lerned it weel and boldely
Fro woorde to woord till accordyng to þe Note
Twyes on þe daye it passed þurgh his throte
To scole warde and homwarde whenne he wente
On Cristes moder sette he all his entente
As I haue seide þurgh out the Iurye
This litel Childe as he come to and froo
Full merely þanne wolde he syng and crye
O alma Redemptoris euer moo
The swetnesse hath his herte perced soo
Of Cristes moder / þat to hir to praye
He can nat stynte of syngyng by þe waye
Oure first Foo þe serpent Sathanas
Þat hath in Iewes herte his waspes neste
Vp swelled and seid O . hebreak peple allas
Is þis a thyng to you þat is honeste
Þat suche a boy shall walke as hym leste
In your dete and syng of suche sentence
Whiche is a yenste youre lawes reuꝰerence
Fro thens þe Iewes haue conspired
Þis Innocente out of þis worlde to enchace
An homycide therto haue they hyred
Þat lay in a waite in a preuy place
And as this Childe gan forth by to pace
Þis fals Iewe hym hente and helde hym faste
And kytte his throte and drough hym at þe laste
I saye þtat in a wardrope þei hym threwe
Where as þese Iewes th purgen ther entraile
O cursed folk O herodes all newe
What may youre euel entent you aduaile
Murdre wole oute certeynly it wole nat faile
And namely þere þe honorur of god shuld sprede
Þe blood out crieth on youre cursed dede
O Martir sounded to virginite
Now maist þou syng folwyng euer in oone
The whight lambe celestial qd she
Of whiche þe grete Euangeliste seynt Iohn
In pathmos wrete whiche saith þtat they goon
By fore þe lambe and syng a song full newe
Þat neuꝰere flesshly women they knewe
This pore widewe waites all þis nyght
After þis litel childe but he yet comes nought
For whiche as sone as it was dayes light
With face pale and drede and besy thought
She hath at scole and elles where hym sought
Tilt finally she gan hym aspye
Þat he was seen last in þe Iurye
With modres pete in herte enclosed
She goth as she were half out of hir mynde
To euꝰery place where she hath supposed
By likelyhode hir Childe for to fynde
And euer on Cristes moder meke and kynde
She cryed and at þe last þus she wrought
She frayned and she prayed petously
To euꝰery Iewe þat duelled in the place
To telle hir if hir Childe wente þer by
They saide nay / but Ihu of his garace
Yaf in hir thought in a litel space
Þat in þat place after hir soone she cried
Where as he was caste in a pytte by side
O grete god þat ꝑperformest thy laude
By mouth of Innocentez loo here thy myght
The gēmme of chastite this Emeraude
And eke of Martirdome þe Rubie bright
There he wtith throte y kutte lay vp right
He Alma Redemptoris gan to syngg
So lowde þat all þe place gan to ryng
Þe Cristen folk þat þurgh þe strete wente
In come for to wundre on this þing
And hastely for þe ꝓprovoste sente
He come a noone with out tarying
And heried Criste þat is heuene kyng
And eke his moder honorur of mankynde
And after þat þe Iewes lete he bynde
Þis Childe with petous lamentacou
Vp taken was syngyng þis song alwaye
And wtith honorur of grete ꝓprocessiou
They caried hym to þe nexte abbey
His moder swownyng by the bere laye
Vnnethes myght þe peple þat was there
This newe Rachel bryng from the bere
With torment and with shamefull deth eche one
Þis ꝓprovoste dooth these Iewes for to sterve
That of this murdre wiste and þat a noone
He nolde non suche cursednesse obserue
Euel shall thaue þat euel wole deserue
Therfore wtith wilde hors h dede hem drawe
And after þat he heng hem by the Mawe
Vpon þe bere ay lithe þis Innocente
By fore þe high autier while þe masse laste
And after þat þe Abbot with þe Couente
Spedde hym to berye hym full faste
And whanne þe holy water he on hym caste
Yet spake þis Childe whan spreyned was þe water
And sang O alma Redemptoris mater
This Abbot whiche was an holy man
As Munkes ben or elles aught for to be
This yong Childe to coniure he by gan
And seid O dere Childe I halse the
In þe vertue of þe holy Trinite
Telle me what is the cause þe for to syng
Sith þat thy throte is kutte at my semyng
My throte is kutte vn to my Nekke boon
Saide þis Childe and as by weye of kynde
I shuld haue be deed ya long tyme a goon
But Ihu Criste as ye in bokes fynde
Wole þat his glory laste and be in mynde
And for þe worship of his moder dere
Yet may I syng O Alma loude and clere
This welle of mercy Cristes moder dere swete
I loved all wey after my konnyng
And whan þat I my lyfe shuld lete
To me she come and bad me for to syng
This Antiewne verrely in my deying
As ye haue herde and when þat I had song
Me þought she leide a greyne vnder my tong
Wherfore I syng and syng mote certeyn
In honoure of þat blisfull maide free
Till fro my tong taken is þe greyn
And after þat þus saide she to me
My litel Childe now wole I fetche þe
Whan þat þi greyne is fro thy tong y take
Be nout a gaste I wole the nat forsake
This holy Monke þis Abbot hym mene I
It oute caught and toke a wey þe greyne
And he gaf vp þe gooste full softely
And whanne þe Abbot hath þe wonder seyne
His salte terys strike doun as reyne
And gruf he fele all platte to þe ground
And stille he lay as he hadde ben y bounde
The couente eke lay vp on þe pavymente
Wepyng and heryng Cristes moder dere
And after þat þei rysen and forth þei wente
And toke a weye þis Martir fro the bere
And in a tumbe of marble stones clere
Enclosed they þis litel body swete
There he is now god leve vs for to mete
O yong hugh of lyncoln y slayn also
With Cursed Iewes as it is notable
For it is but a litel while a goo
Praye for vs synfull folke on stable
Þat of his mercy god so mercyable
Vp on vs his grete mercy multiplie
For reuꝰerence of his moder Marie
Here begyneth the ꝓprolog of the Munke
Whanne ended was þe tale of Mellibe
And of prudence and of her benignite
Our Ooste saide as I am synfull man
And by þe precious Corpus madryan
I had leuꝰere thanne a barelle ale
Þat good lief my wyfe had herde þis tale
For she ne is no thyng of suche pacience
As was this mellibeus prudence
By goddes bones whanne I bete my knaues
She brought me the grete clubbed staves
And cryeth slee the dogges euꝰeryche one
And breke bothe bak and bone
And if þat eny neyborur of myne
Wole nat in Chirche to my wyfe enclyne
Or be so hardy to hir do trespace
When she cometh home she rumpeth in my face
And cryeth fals cowerd wreke thy wyfe
By Corpus bonys I wole haue thy knyfe
And þou shal haue my distaf and go spynne
From day to nyght right þus she wole begynne
Allas she seith þat euꝰere I was shape
To wedde a mylkesoppe or a cowerd ape
That wole be ouꝰere ladde wtith euꝰery wight
Thou darst nat stande by þi wyfe a right
This is my lyfe but if þat I wolde fyght
And out at þe dore a none I mote me dight
Or elles I am loste but if that I
Be lyke a wode lyou full hardy
I wote weel she wole do me slee som day
Som neyborur and þanne go my way
For I am perelous with k knyve in honde
All be it þat I dar nat hir wyth stonde
For she is bygge in armes by my feith
Þat shall he fynde þat hir mys dooth or seith
But lete vs passe awey from this matier
My lord ꝸ monk he seith be mery of chier
For ye shall telle a tale truly
Loo Rouchestre stande here fast by
Ride forth myne owen lord breke nat our game
But by my trouth I knowe nat your name
Whether I shall calle you my lord daūn Iohn
Or dan Thomas or dan Albou
Outher of what hous be ye by yorur fadre kyn
I vowe to god þou haste a full faire skyn
It is a gentil pasture there thow goost
Þow art nat lyke a penant or a goost
Vpon my feith þow art som officere
Som worthy sexteyn or som Celerer
For by my fadres soule as to my dome
Thou art a Maister when þou art at home
No pore cloysterer ner no pore novyce
But gouꝰernour wyly and wyse
And þer with all of braunes and of bones
A weel faryng ꝑpersone for the nones
I pray to god geve hym confusyou
That first the brought in to religiou
Thow woldest haue ben a dredefull wight
Haddest thow as grete leve as thou hast myght
To ꝑperforme all thy lust to engendrure
Thow haddest by goten many a creature
Allas why weres thow so wyde a cope
God yeve me sorwe if I were a pope
Nat only þat euꝰery myghty man
Though he were shore high vpon his panne
Shuld haue a wyfe for all this world is lorne
Religiou hath take vp all the corn
Of tredyng and we borell men ben shrympes
Of feble trees there come wrecched ympes
This maketh þat oure heyres ben so slendre
And feble þat they may nat weel engendre
This maketh þat oure wyfes wole assaye
Religious folk for þei may better paye
Of venus payment thanne may we
God wote no lushbornes paye ye
But nat wroth my lord though þtat I pleye
Full often in game a sothe I haue herde seye
This worthy monke toke all in pacience
And seide I wole done all my diligence
As ferre as sowneth in to honeste
To telle yow a tale or twoo or three
And if yow luste to herkne heder werde
I wole yow seyn the lyfe of seynt Edwarde
Or elles tregedryes first wole I telle
Of whiche I haue an hundrede in my selle
Tregedrye is for to tellen a certeyn storye
As olde bokes maken memorye
Of hem þat stode in grete ꝓprosꝑperite
And is y falle oute of hise degree
In to myserye and endeth wretchedlye
And they ben versefyed comounlye
Of sex feet whiche men clepe examytrou
In prose eke ben endyted many one
And eke in e metre in many sondre wyse
Loo this aught y now to yow suffise
Now herkeneth if you lust now for to here
But first I yow byseche in this manere
Though I by ordre telle nat these thynges
Be it of popes Emꝑperoures or kynges
And after here degre as men writen fynde
But telle hem som by fore som by hynde
And it cometh now to my remembraunce
Haue me excused of myne ignoraunce
Here begynneth the Tale of the Munke
De casibz virorꝭes illustriu
I wole by wayle in mane of tregedrye
The harme of hem þtat stonde in high degree
And felen so þat þꝰere was no remddye
To brynge hem our of þꝰere Aduꝰersite
For certeyn whanne þtat fortune lust to flee
Ther may no man þe cours of hir witholde
Lete no man troste on blynde prosperite
Be war by this example yong and olde
At lucifer though he an Aungel were
And nat a man at hym I wole bygynne
For though fortune may none aūngel dere
From high degree yet felle he for his synne
Doun in to helle where as ye yet is ynne
O lucifer brightest of Aungel alle
Now art þou Sathanas þtat mayst nat twynne
Out of myserie in which thou art falle
Now Adam in the felde of Damacene
With goddes owen fyngre wrought was he
And nat by goten of mannes sparme clene
And welded all paradice sauyng one tree
Had neuꝰere werldly man so high deyree
As Adam till he for his gouꝰernaunce
Was dryuen out of his high ꝓprosꝑperite
To labour and to helle for his myschaunce
¶ Loo Sampsoūn whiche was anunciate
By the Aungel long er hise natyuite
And was to god allmyghty consecrate
And stode in noblesse while he myght see
Was neuꝰer suche an other as was he
To speke of strength and ther to hardynesse
But to hise wyfes tolde he hise secree
Thurgh whiche he slowgh hym self for wretchednesse
¶ Sampsou this noble and myghty Campyou
With outen wepen saf hise hondes tweye
He slough and all to rente the lyou
Toward hise weddyng walkyng by the weye
His fals wyfe coude hym so plese and preye
Till she his counsell knewe and she ontrewe
Vn to hise foos his counsell she gan be wreye
And hym forsoke and toke hym to an other newe
¶ An hundrede foxes toke Sampsou for Ire
And alle her tayles he to guedre bonde
And sette þe foxes tayles on a fyre
For he in euꝰery tayle hadde put a bronde
And they brente alle þe cornes in þat londe
And alle her Olyves and alle her vynes eke
A Thousand men he slough with his honde
And hadde no wepen but an asses cheke
¶ Whan ther were slayn so thursted hym þat he
Was full nygh lorne for whiche he gan to preye
Þat god wolde of his peyne haue som pite
And sende hym drynk or elles must he deye
And of þis asses cheke þat was so dreye
Out of a wang tooth sprang a welle
Of whiche he drank y now soth to telle seye
Thus helped hym god as Iudicūn can telle
¶ By verray force as gazan on a nyght
Mawgre philisians of þat Cite
The gate of þe toun he hath vp pight
And on his bakke y caryed hem hath he
High on an hill where men myght hem see
O noble and myghty Sampsou myghty and dere
Ne hadde thou tolde to women thy secree
In all þis worlde ne hadde ben þi pere
¶ This Sampsou neuꝰere citter drank ne wyne
Ne on his hed neuꝰer come rasour ner sheere
By precepte of the Massanger dyuyne
For all hise strength was in hise heer
And fully xxtiri yeer by yeer
He hadde of Isrl the gouꝰernaunce
But after sone shall he wepe many a teer
For women shall bryng hym to myschaunce
¶ Vn to his lēmman Dalida he tolde
That in his heres all hise strength it laye
And falsly to hise fomen she hym solde
And slepyng vp on hir barme on a daye
She made to clyppe or shere hise here a waye
And made hise fomen all hise crafte espyen
And when þtat they hym founde in suche arraye
They bounde hym faste and put out hise eyen
¶ But er hise heer was y clipped or y shaue
Ther was no bonde þat hym myght bynde
But now is he in prisou put in a kave
Where þat they made hym at þe querne grynde
O noble Sampsoūn strenggst of mankynde
.b. Now maist thow wepe with thyne eyen blynde
.a. O whilom Iuge in glorye and Richesse
Sithens thow art from weel fallen in to wretchednesse
¶ The ende of these caytyfes was as I shall seye
Hise fomen made a feste opon a daye
And made hym as her fool by forn hem pleye
And þis was in a temple of grete arraye
But at þe last he made a foule affraye
For he ij postes shoke and made hem falle
And doun fel þe temple and all þꝰere it laye
And slough hise fomen hym self and eke his fomen alle
¶ This is to seye the princes euꝰerychou
And eke a thousand bodyes were there slayn
With fallyng of þe grete temple of ston
Of Sampsou ne wole I nomore sayn
Be war of þese examples olde and playn
Þat no men telle here counsell to here wyves
Of suche thynges as they wold haue secre fayn
Yf that it touche her lymys or her lyves
¶ Of hercule þe souꝰerayn Conquerour
Sithen his werkes levede and hie renoun
For in his st tyme of strength he bare þe flour
He slough and rafte the skyn fro the leou
He of Sentaures leyde the booste a doun
He Arpyes slough þe cruel brydddes felle
He golden appels rafte the dragou
He drowe out Gerborois þe hounde of helle
¶ He slough þe cruell tyraunt buserus
And made hise hors to frete hym flessh and bon
He slough þe verray serpent venenous
Of Achilles twoo hornes brake he one
He slough Cacus in a kave of stone
He slough þe geaunt Anteus the strong
He slough þe grysely bore and þat a none
And bare the hed vpon hise nekke long
¶ Was neuꝰere wight sithe þe werlde by gan
Þat slough so many monstres as dede he
Thurgh out this wilde world hise name ran
What for hise strength and for hise bounte
And euꝰery Reame mente he for to see
He was so strong þat no man myght hym lette
And bothe þe worldes endes seith trophee
In stede of boundes he a pyler sette
¶ A leman hadde þis noble Campyou
Þat hight Dyamyr as fressh as may
And as þe Clerkes maken menciou
She hath hym sente a shirte fresh and gay
Allas þis sherte and welaway
Envenemed was subtily with all
Þat er he had wered it half a day
It made hise bones from hise flessh to fall
¶ But nthelesse som Clerkes hir excusyn
By one þat hight Nessus þat it maked
Be as be may I wole hir nat accusen
But on hise bak þis sherte he were all naked
Till þat hise flessh was for þe venom blaked
And when he sawe non other remedye
In hote coles he hath hym self raked
For with venom disdeyned he to deye
¶ Thus starf this worthy myghty hercules
Loo who may truste on fortune eny throwe
For hym þat folweth all þis world a prees
Er he be war is ofte y leyde full lowe
Full wise is he þat hym self can knowe
Be war for whanne þtat fortune luste to glose
Thanne wayteth she hir man doun to throwe
By suche a wey as he leest suppose
The myghty Trone the precious tresour
The glorious ceptre and royal maieste
That had þe kyng Nabugodonosor
With tong vnnethes may descryved be
He twyes toke Irlm the Cite
Þe vessell of the temple he with hym ladde
At Babylou was hise souꝰerayn see
In whiche his glorye and hise delite hadde
¶ The fairest Children of the blode royall
Of Irlm de dede do gylde a non
And maked eche of hem to ben his thrall
Among alle other Danyell was one
Þat was the wisest Childe of euꝰerychou
For he þe dremes of þe kyng expouned
Wher as in Caldeye Clerk was ther non
Þat wost to what fyne his dremes sowned
¶ This proude kyng dede make a statue of golde
Sexty cubites long and vij in brede
To suche an Image bothe yong and olde
Comaunded he to lowte and haue in drede
Or in a furneys full of flammes rede
He shuld be brente þat wolde nat obeye
But neuꝰere wolde assent to þat dede
Danyel ne hise yong felowes tweye
¶ This kyng of kyngges proude and elate
He went þat god þat sitte in maieste
Ne myght hym nat byreve of his estate
And sothenly he loste hise dignite
And like a beest he semed for to be
And ete hay as an oxe and lay þꝰere oute
In reyn with wylde beestes walked he
Tyll certeyn tyme was comen a boute
¶ And like an Egles federes was hise heeres
Hise nayles like bryddes clawes were
God releved hym a certeyn yeeres
And gaf hym witte and þanne wtith many a teere
He thanked god and euꝰere his lyfe in feere
Was he to done a mys or more trespace
And er þat tyme he layd was on beere
He knewe weel þt god was full of myght and garace
¶ His sone whiche þat hight Balthasar
That helde þe regne after his fadres daye
He by hise Fadre coude nat be war
For proude he was of herte and of arraye
And eke an ydolatre was he aye
His high estate assured hym in pride
But fortune cast hym doun and þꝰere he laye
And sothenly hise regne gan deuyde
¶ A feste he made vn to his lordes alle
Vpon a tyme he made hym blithe to be
And thanne hise officers gan he calle
Goo bryng forth þe vessels qd he
Whiche þat my fadre in hise ꝓprosꝑperite
Out of the temple of Irlm by rafte
And to oure high goddes þanke wee
Of honour þat oure eldres with vs lefte
¶ His wyfe hise lordes and hise Concubynes
Ay dronken whiles her appetite laste
Out of þese noble vessels sundry wynes
And on a wal þis kyng hise eyen caste
And saw an arme hande armeles þtat wrote full faste
For fer of whiche he quoke and sighed sore
This hande þat baltazar made so sore a gaste
Wrote mane techel phares and no more
¶ In all þat londe Magicion was þꝰere non
Þat coude expoune what þis lree mente
But Danyell expouned it a none
And seid kyng god to thy fadre sente
Glory and honour regne tresour and rente
And he was proude and no thyng god he dradde
And þꝰerfor god grete wreche vpon hym sente
And hym by rafte the regne þat he hadde
¶ He was out caste of mannys companye
With asses was hise habytacoūn
And ete hay as a beste in wete and drye
Till þat he knewe by grace and by resou
Þat god of heuene hath domynacou
Ouꝰere euꝰery regne and euꝰery creature
And þanne hadde god of hym compassiou
And hym restored hise regne and hise figure
¶ Eke þou þat art hise sone arte proude also
And knowest alle these thyngges pryuely
And art rebell to god and art his Foo
Thou dranke eke of hise vessels boldely
Thy wyfe eke and thy wenches synfully
Dranke of þe same vessels sondry wynes
And honoured fals goddes cursedly
Therfore to the shapen grete peyne is
¶ This hand was sent fro god þat on þe wall
That wrote Mane thechel phares trust me
Thy reigne is doon thou weyest nat at all
Dyuyded is thy reigne and it shall be
To Medys and to ꝑpersys gouen qd he
And thilke same nyght the kyng was slawe
And daryus occupieth hise degree
Though he þꝰer to ne hadde neyther right ne lawe
¶ Lordyngꝭes here by example ye may take
How þat in lordship is no sekernesse
For whan fortune wile a man forsake
He bereth a wey hise regne and hise richesse
And eke hise frendes bothe more and lesse
And what man hath frendes thurgh fortune
Mys happe wole make hem enmyes I gesse
This ꝓprouꝰerve is full sooth and full comune
¶ Cenobia of Palyme the quene
As writen ꝑperisens of hir noblesse
So worthy was in armes and so kene
That no wight passed hir in hardynesse
Ne in lynage ne in other gentylnesse
Of þe kynges blode of ꝑpersye is she descended
I sey þat she ne had nat most fairenesse
But of hir shappe she myght nat be amended
¶ From Childehode I fynde þat she fledde
Office of women and in to þe wood she wente
And many a wylde hertes blood she shedde
With arwes brode þat she to hem sente
She was so swyfte þat she a none hem hente
And whanne þtat she was older she wolde kylle
Leons leoꝑperdes and beres all to rente
And in her armes welded them at hir wille
¶ She durste wilde beestes dennes seke
And renne to the monteyn all þe nyght
And slepe vndre a bush she coude eke
Wrastelyn by verray fors and myght
With any yong man were he neuꝰer so wight
Þꝰere myght nothyng in hir armes stonde
She kepte hir maydenhode fro euꝰery wight
To no man deyned hir to be bonde
¶ But at þe last hir frendes haue hir maryed
To Odonake a prince of þat Cite
All wer it so þat she hem long taryed
And he shall vnderstande how þat he
Hadde suche fantasies as hadde she
But nerthelesse when they were knytte in fere
Thy lyved in ioye and in felicite
For eche of hem hadde other lief and dere
¶ Saf one thyng þat she ne wolde neuꝰere assente
By no weye þat he shuld by hir lye
But ones for it was hir pleyne entente
To haue a childe the worlde to multiplye
And also sone as she myght aspye
Þat she was nat with childe wtith þat dede
Þanne wolde she suffre hym done hise fantasye
Eft sone and nat but ones out of drede
¶ And if she were with childe at thilk caste
Nomore shuld he pleye thilk game
Till fourty dayes were paste
Thanne wold she ones suffre to do þe same
All were þis odonake wylde or tame
He gate no more of hir for thus she saide
It was to wyves lechery and shame
In other case if þat men myght hem be holde payed
¶ Twoo sones with þis odonak had she
The whiche she kepte in vꝰertue and letterure
w to our tale torne we
I say þat worshipfull creature
And wise þꝰerwith and large with mesure
So penyable in the werre and Curteys eke
Nomore labour myght in werre endure
Was none they all þis worlde we shuld seke
. Hir riche array myght nat be tolde
As weel in vessell as in clothyng
She was all cladde in perre and in golde
And eke she lefte nat for none huntyng
To haue of sondry tongges folk knowyng
Whan þat she leyser hadde and for to entende
To lerne bokys was all hir likyng
How she in vꝰertue myght hir lyfe dispende
. And shortely of þis for to entrete
So dowty was hir husbond as she
Þat þei conquered many reignes grete
In the oriente with many a faire Cite
Aꝑpertenaunt vn to the mageste
Of Rome and with strong honde halde hem faste
Ne neuꝰere myght her fomen do hem flee
Ay whiles þat Odonak dayes lafte
. Her batailes who so ljst hem for to rede
A gayn Soper þe kyng and other moo
And how þat all þe ꝓprocesse fell in dede
Why she conquered and what title had þꝰerto
And after of hir myscheef and of hir woo
How þat she was byseged and y take
Lete hym vn to my Maister petrark goo
Þat writith y now of þis I vndertake
. Whan Odonake was ded she myghtly
The reignes helde and with hir ꝓpropre honde
A gayn hir foos she faught truly
Þat þꝰer ne was kyng ne prynce in all þat londe
Þat he ne was glad if he þat grace fonde
Þat she ne wold vpon hise londe werreye
With hir þei made a lyaunce by bonde
To be in pes and lete hir ryde and pleye
. The Emꝑperour of Rome Claudius
Ne hym by forne the romayne Galyene
Ne durst neuꝰere be so coragious
Ne non Ermyne ne none Egipciene
Ne none Surryene ne non Arabyene
With in felde þat durst with hir to fight
Leste þat she wolde with hir hondes hem sleen
Or with hir menye putte them to flyght
In kynges habite wente hir sones twoo
As heires of hir Reignes alle
And hermanne and Timalito
Here names were as ꝑpersions hem Calle
But fortune ay hath in hir hony galle
This myghty quene may no thyng endure
Fortune out of hir Reigne made hir falle
To wretchednesse and to mysauenture
. Aurelian whan þat the gouꝰernaunce
Of Rome come in to hise handes tweye
Toward Cenobie he made his chaunce
He made hir flee and at þe last hir hente
And fetered hir and eke hir children tweye
And wanne þe lond and home to Rome þei wente
A mong these other thynges þat he h wanne
Hir chaar þat wrought with gold was and perre
. This grete Romayne þis Aurelius
Hath with hym ladde for þat men shuld see
By fore hise Tryumphe walketh she
With gylte cheynes on hir nekke hongyng
Coroned she was as after hir degree
And full of perre charged hir clothyng
Allas fortune she saide þat whilom was
Dredefull to kynges and to Emꝑperours
Now gawleth all þe peple on hir allas
And she þat helmed was in starke stoures
Shall on hir hedde now bere a vitre myte
And she þat bar þe ceptre full of floures
Shall bye a distaf hir coste for to quyte
. O noble o worthy petre glorye of spayne
Whom fortune helde so high in mageste
Wel ought men thy petous deth complayne
Thy bastard brother made the to flee
And after at a sege by subtilite
Thow were be trayed and ledde to his tente
Where as he with hise owen had hande slow the
Succedyng in thy reigne and in the rente
Þe felde of snowe with þe Egle blak ther ynne
Caught with þe lyme rede colours as þe glede
He brew þis cursednesse and all þe synne
. The wikked neste was werker of þis nede
Nought Charles Olifer þat ay toke good hede
Of trouth and honour but armorekke
Genilou Oliuꝰere corrupte for nede
Broughtest þis worthy kyng to suche brekke
Worthy Petre kyng of Cipre also
That Alizaundre wan by high mageste
Full many an hethen wroughtest þow in woo
Of whiche þine owen lieges hadde enuye
And for no thyng but for thy Chyualrie
They in thy bedde han slay the by þe morwe
Thus gan fortune gouꝰerne and guye
And out of Ioye bryng in to sorwe
Of Mellane grete Barnebe viscounte
Sithen in estate þow clomben were so high
Thy brother sone þat was þi double alye
For he thy nevewe was and sone in lawe
With ynne his prisou made the to dye
But why ne how wote I þat thow were slawe
. Of the Erle hugelyne of pise þe langour
Ther may no tung telle for pite
But litel out of pyse stant a tour
In whiche tour in prisou put was he
And with hym been hise childre three
. Þe oldest scarsely v yeer was of age
Allas fortune it was cruelte
Suche bryddes for to putte in suche a cage
Dampned he was to deye in þat prisou
For Roger whiche þat Bisshop of pyse
Hadde on hym made a fals suggestiou
Thurgh whiche þe peple gan on hym a ryse
And putte hym in prisou in suche a wyse
As ye haue herde and mete and drynk he hadde
So smal þat vnnethe it may suffise
And þꝰerwith all it was full pore and badde
. On a day byfel þat in that houre
When þat hise mete was wonte to be brought
Þe Iayller shette þe dorys of þe toure
He harde it weel but he sawe it nought
And in his herte a none þꝰere fel a thought
Þat they for hungre wold done hym deyen
Allas qd he allas þat I was wrought
Ther with þe teeres fel from hise eyen
His yong sone þat thre yeer was of age
Vn to hym said Fadre why do ye wepe
Whanne wole þe Iayller bryng our potage
Is there no morsell brede þat ye dede kepe
I am so hungry that I may nat slepe
Now wold to god þat I myght slepe euꝰere
Thenne shuld none hungre in my wombe crepe
There is no thyng Saf bred þat me were leuꝰere
. Þus day by daye þis child gan to crye
Till in his fadres barme a doun it laye
And seide Fare weel fadre for me moūn dye
And kyssed hise Fadre and deyed þe same daye
And whan the wofull Fadre herde hym saye
For woo hise armes two he gan to byte
And seid Allas fortune and welawaye
Thy fals whele my woo I may all wyte
. His children seyng þat it for hungre was
Þat he hise armes gnewe and nat for woo
They seid Fadre do nat so allas
But rather ete þe flessh vpon vs twoo
Our flessh þow gaf vs take our flessh vs froo
And ete y nough right thus to hym they seide
And after þat with ynne a daye or twoo
They leide hem doun in hise lappe and deyed
. Hym self despeyred eke for hungre starfe
Thus ended is this myghty Erle of Pyse
For high estate fortune from hym karfe
Of hise tregetrye it ought y nough suffise
Who so wolde here it in a lenger wise
Rede þe grete poete of Itaill
That high Daunte for he can it deuyse
Fro poynt to poynte nat one woord wold he faille
. All though þat Nero were als vicious
As any fende þat lythe full lowe a doun
Yet he as telleth vs Swenetheus
This wide worlde hadde in subieccon
Bothe est and west and septemtryoun
Of Rubies saphires and of perles white
Wer alle hise clothes brouthered vp and doun
For in gemmes grete he gan delite
. More delicate more pompous of arraye
More proude was neuꝰer Emꝑperourer thanne he
Þat ilke cloth þat he had wered one daye
After þat tyme he wold it neuꝰere see
Nettes of gold threde had he gret plente
To fisshen in Tybre whan hym lust to pleye
Hise lustes were as lawe in his degree
For fortune as hise frende wolde hym obeye
. He Rome brente for hise delicys
The senatours slow he vpon a daye
To wepe how þat men wolde wepe and crye
And slowgh hise brother and by hise suster laye
His moder made he in a petous arraye
For he hir wombe dede slitte to be holde
Where he conceyued was so welaweye
That he so litell of hise moder tolde
. Noo teere out of hise eyen yede for þat sight
Ne came but saide a faire woman was she
Grete wondre was þat he coude or myght
Be domes man of hir dede beaute
The wyne to bryng comaunded he
He drank a none non other woo he made
Whanne myght is ioyned to cruelte
Allas to depe wole the venom wade
. In youthe a Maister had þis Emꝑperour
To teche hym letture and curtasye
For of moralite he was þe floure
As in his tyme or bokes lye
And whiles hise Maister of hym had þe Maistrye
He made hym so konnyng and so souple
Þat long tyme it was or tyranrye
Or eny vice in hym durst oncouple
. This Seneca of whiche I deuyse
By cause Nero hadde of hym suche drede
For he for vices wolde hym chastise
Discretely as by woord and nat by dede
Sir wolde he sayn an Emꝑperour mote nede
Be vꝰertuous and hate Tyrannye
For whiche he hym in bath made blede
On bothe hise armes tyll he must dye
. This Nero hadde eke of a custumance
In youthe a yenst hise Maister for to ryse
Whiche afterward hym thought a grete greuance
Therfor he made hym deye in this wyse
But nthelesse þis Senek the wyse
Chees in a bath to deye in hise mane
Rather þanne haue an other torment in oþꝰer guyse
And thus hath Nero slayn hise moder dere
. Now fel it so þat fortune luste no lengger
The high pride of Nero to cheryce
For though he was strong yet was she strengger
She thought thus by god I am to nyce
To sette a man þat is fulfilled of vyce
In hise degre an Emꝑperorur hym calle
By god out of hise sete I wole hym tryce
Whan he leest weneth sonest shall he falle
. The peple Roos vpon hym on a nyght
That with his eeres harde he howe they sayde
Where is this fals traytour Nerou
For fere all moost out ot his witte he braide
And to hise goddes petously he prayed
For socorur but it myght nat betyde
For drede of þis hym thought þtat he dyed
And ranne in to a gardeyn hym to hyde
. And in this gardeyn fonde he charles tweye
That seten by a fyre full grete and rede
And to þe cherles two he gan to preye
To sleen hym and to guyrden of his hede
That to hise body whan þtat he were dede
Were no despite y done ner no diffame
Hym self he slough he coude no better reed
Of whiche fortune lowgh and made a game
. Was neuꝰere Capiten vnder a kyng
Þat reignes more put in subieccon
Ne strenger was in felde of all thyng
As in hise tyme ne gretter of renoun
Ne more pompouse in high psumpcou
Thenne Oliferne whiche fortune ay beste
So likerously and ledde hym vp and doun
Tyll þat hise hed was of er than he wyste
. Nout þtat þis world hadde of hym awe
For lesyng of richesse and of liberte
But he made euꝰery man reneye hise lawe
Nabugodonosor was lord said he
None other god shuld honoured be
A yenst hise heste no wight dar trespace
Saf in Bethulia a straunge Cite
Where Eliachym a preest was in þat place
. But take kepe of the deth of Olipherne
A mydde hise ooste he dronken lay an nyght
With in hise tente large as is a berne
And for all hise pompe and all hise myght
Iudith a woman as he lay vp right
Slepyng hise hed of smot and fro his tente
Full pryuely she stale from euꝰery wight
And a yen to Betulie with þe hed she wente
. What nedeth of a kyng Antiochus
To telle hise high and royall mageste
Hise high pride hise werkes venenous
For suche an other was neuꝰer none as he
Redeth whiche þat he was in Machabee
And rede þe proude woordes þat he seide
And why he fel from high ꝓprosperite
And in an hall how wrecchedly he deyed
. Fortune so hadde hym enlyaunced in pride
That vꝰerely he wende he myght atteyne
Vn to þe sterres vpon euꝰery side
And in a balaunce to weye þe mounteyne
And alle þe flodes of the see restreyne
And goddes peple had he moost in hate
Hem wolde he slee in torment and peyne
Wenyng þat god ne myght hise pride abate
. And for þat Nichamone and Tymothee
With Iewes were venquisshed myghtly
Vn to þe Iewes suche an hate had he
That he greithed hise chaar full hastely
And swore and seid full despitously
Vn to Irlm he wolde eft sone
To wreke hise yre on it full cruelly
But of hise purpos he was lette full sone
. God of hise manace hym so sore smote
With invisible wounds ay vncurable
Þat in hise guttes karfe so and bote
Þat hise peynes were inportable
And certeynly þe wretche was resonable
For many mennes guttes did he peyn
But fro his purpos cursed and dampnable
For all hise smerte he nolde hym restreyne
. But badde a none appayrelen hise ooste
And sothenly er he was of ware
God auaunted all hise pride and all hise booste
For he so sore fele out of hise chare
Þat he hurte hise lymes and all hise skyn to tare
So þat he ne myght goo ne ryde
But in chayer men a bout hym bare
All for bruzed bothe bak and syde
. The wreche of god hym smote so cruelly
Þat in hise body wikked wormes crepte
And þꝰerwith all he stanke so horrybly
Þat none of all hise menye þat hym kepte
Whether so þat he woke or elles slepte
Ne myght nat þe stynk of hym endure
In this myschief he wayled and eke wepte
And knewe god lord of euꝰery creature
. The story of Alizaundre is so comune
Þat euꝰery wight þat hath discrecoūn
Hath herde somwhat or all of hise fortune
This wide worlde as in conclusiou
He wanne by strength or for hise high renoun
They wexen glad for pes vn to hym sende
The pride of man and beest he leyde a doun
Whersoo he come in to the worldes ende
. Comꝑperisou myght neuꝰer be maked
By twix hym and an other Conquerour
For all þis worlde for drede of hym hath quaked
He was of knyghthood and of fredome þe flour
Fortune hym made þe heire of hir honour
Saf wyne and women no thyng myght he swage
His high entent in Armes and labour
So was he lovyng in grete corage
. What pite were it to hym though I yow tolde
Of Daryus and an hundred thousand moo
Of kynges prynces earles bolde
Whiche he conquered and brought in to woo
I sey as fer as man may ride or goo
This world was hise what shuld I more devyse
For though I write or tolde yow euꝰere moo
Of hise knyghthood it myght nat suffise
. Twelf yeer he reigned as seith Machabee
Phillippes sone of Macedonye he was
Þat first was kyng of Grece the contree
O worthy gentill Alexander Allas
That euꝰere shuld falle suche a caas
Enpoysoned of thy folke thow were
Thyne v. fortune hath torned in to an aas
And yet for þe ne wepe she neuꝰer a teere
. Who shall yeven teeres men to compleyne
The deth of gentilnesse and of fraunchyse
That all þe world wielded at his demeyne
And yet hym thought it myght nat suffise
So full was hise corage of high empryse
Allas who shall helpe me to endyte
Fals fortune and poysoūn to despise
The whiche twoo of all thise woo I wite
. By wisdom manhode and by laboure
Fro humblehode and fro royall mageste
Vp Roos Iulius the royall Conquerour
Þat all the occident by lond and see
By strength of hand or elles by tretee
And vn to Rome made hem tributarye
And sethens of Rome þe Emꝑperour was he
Tyll þat fortune was hise aduꝰersarye
¶ O myghty Cesar þat in Thessalie
A yenst pompeyus Fadre thyne in lawe
Þat of the oryent hadde all the chyualrye
As fer as þe day begynneth to dawe
Though thurgh thy knyghthode þou hast hem take ⁊ slawe
Saf fewe folk þat with pompeyus fledde
Þurgh whiche þou puttest all þe oryent in awe
Thank fortune þat so weel the spedde
¶ But now a litel while I wole be wayle
This pompeyus this noble gouꝰernour
Of Rome þe whiche þat fleigh at þis batayle
I seye one of hise men a fals traitour
His hed of smote to wynne hym fauour
Of Iulius and hym þe hed brought
Allas Pompeye of the orient Conquerorur
Þat fortune vn to suche a fyne brought
¶ To Rome a yen repaireth Iulius
With hise tryumphe laureat full high
But on a tyme Brutus Cassius
Þat euꝰere hadde of hise estate enuye
Full pyuely he made conspiracye
A yenst this Iulius in subtyle wyse
And cast þe place in whiche he shall dye
With bodkyns as I shall you devyse
¶ This Iulius to þe Capitoill wente
Vpon a daye as he was wonte to gone
And in þe Capitoille a none hym hente
This fals Brutus and hise foule foone
And styked hym with bodkyns a noone
With many a woounde and þus they lete hym lye
But neuꝰere grutched at no strook but one
Or elles at twoo but if the storye lye
¶ So manly was this Iulius of herte
And so weel lyved in stately honeste
Þat if hise dedly woūndes so sore dede smerte
Hise mantel ouꝰere hise hippes yet kest he
For no man shuld seen hise pryuete
And as he lay deying in a trance
And wist verely þat ded was he
Of honeste yet hadde he remembraūnce
¶ Lucane to þe this storye I recomende
And to Sweten and to valerius also
Þat of þis storye writeth woord and ende
How þat to these grete Conquerorurs twoo
Fortune was first frende and sithen a foo
No man ne trost vpon hir fauour long
But haue hir in a wayte euꝰere moo
Witnesse on alle these Conquerorurs strong
¶ This riche Cresus whilom kyng of lyde
Of whiche Cresus Ciquus sore hym dredde
Yet was he caught a mong all hise pride
And to be brente men to the fire hym ledde
But suche a reyne doun fro the welkyn shedde
Þat slough þe fire and made hym to scape
But to be war yet no grace he hadde
Till fortune of the galwys made hym gape
¶ Whan he escaped was he can nat stente
For to be gynne a newe reyn a yen reneȝayne
He wende weel for þat fortune hym sente
Suche happe þat he escaped thurgh þe rayne
Þat of hise foes he myght nat be slayne
And suche a swefne vpon a nyght he mette
Of whiche he was so proude and eke fayne
Þat in vengeaūnce he all hise herte sette
¶ Vpon a tree he was as hym thought
There Iubiter hym wesshe bothe hals and syde
And phebus eke a fayre towayl hym brought
To drye hym with and þꝰerfore wex hise pride
And to hyse doutꝰere þat stode hym be syde
Whiche þat he knewe in high sentence habounde
He badde hir telle hym what it signifyed
And she his dremes by gan þus expounde
¶ The tree qd she the galwes is to mene
And Iubiter bytokeneth snow and reyne
And phebus with hise towayl so clene
Thoo ben þe sonne stremes for to seyne
Thow shalt hangged be Fader certeyne
Rayne shall þe wassh and sonne shal the drye
Thus warned she hym full platte and full pleyn
His doutꝰere þat called was phanye
¶ An hangged was Crisus the proude kyng
His royall trone myght hym nat availe
Tregedye is non other mane thyng
Ne can in syng synnyng crye ne be wayle
But þat fortune all weye wole assayle
With on war stroke the reignes þat be proude
For when men trosten hir þan wole she fayle
And couꝰere hir bright face wtith a cloude
Now endith the Monke his tale
(base) ¶ The prohemie of the Mannes tale of Lawe
(base) Ovre hoost saw wel that the brighte sonne
(base) The ark of his artificial day hath ronne
(base) The ferthe part and half an hour and moore
(base) And thogh he were nat depe ystert in loore
(base) He wiste it was the eightene the day
(base) Of April / that is messager to May
(base) And saw wel / that the shadwe of euery tree
(base) Was as in lengthe / the same quantitee
(base) That was the body erect that caused it
(base) And therfore by the shadwe / he took his wit
(base) That Phebus / which that shoon so cleer and brighte
(base) Degrees was fourty fyue clombe on highte
(base) And for that day / as in that latitude
(base) It was ten at the Clokke he gan conclude
(base) And sodeynly / he plighte his hors aboute
(base) ¶ Lordynges quod he I warne yow al this route
(base) The ferthe party of this day is goon
(base) Now for the loue of god / and of Seint Iohn
(base) Leseth no tyme / as ferforth as ye may
(base) Lordynges the tyme / it wasteth nyght and day
(base) And steleth from vs / what pryuely slepynge
(base) And what thurgh necligence / in oure wakynge
(base) As dooth the streem that turneth neuere agayn
(base) Descendynge fro the montaigne in to playn
(base) Wel kan Senec and many a Philosophre
(base) Biwaillen tyme / moore than gold in cofre
(base) For los of catel may recouered be
(base) But los of tyme shendeth vs quod he
(base) It wol nat come agayn / withouten drede
(base) Namoore / than wol Malkyns maydenhede
(base) Whan she hath lost it / in hir wantownesse
(base) Lat vs nat / mowlen thus in ydelnesse
(base) ¶ Sire man of lawe quod he / so haue ye blys
(base) Tel vs a tale anon / as forward is
(base) Ye been submitted / thurgh youre free assent
(base) To stonden in this cas / at my Iuggement
(base) Aquiteth yow now / of youre biheste
(base) Thanne haue ye doon youre deuoir atte leeste
(base) ¶ Hoost quod he depardieux ich assente
(base) To breken forward / is nat myn entente
(base) Biheste is dette / and I wol holde fayn
(base) Al my biheste / I kan no bettre sayn
(base) Plese yow / and therto wole I do my payne
(base) For swich lawe / as a man yeueth another wight /
(base) He sholde hymself / vsen it by right
(base) Thus wol oure text / but nathelees certein
(base) I kan right now / no thrifty tale seyn
(base) That Chaucer / thogh he kan but lewedly
(base) On metres / and on rymyng craftily
(base) Hath seyd hem / in swich englissh as he kan
(base) Of olde tyme / as knoweth many a man
(base) And if he ne haue nat seyd hem / leeue brother
(base) In o book he hath seyd hem in another
(base) For he hath toold / of louers vp and doun
(base) Mo than Ouide / made of mencioun
(base) In his epistles / that been ful olde
(base) What sholde I tellen hem / syn they been tolde
(base) In yowthe he made / of Ceys and Alcione
(base) And sithen hath he spoke of euerychone
(base) Thise noble wyues / and thise loueres eke
(base) Who so that wole / his large volum seke
(base) Clepyd the Seintes legende of Cupide
(base) Ther maystow seen /. the large woundes wyde
(base) Of Lucresse / and of Babilan Tisbee
(base) The swerd of Dido / for the false Enee
(base) The tree of Phillis / for hir Demophon
(base) The pleinte of Dianire / and of Hermyoun
(base) Of Adriane / and of ysiphilee
(base) The barayne Ile / stondynge in the See
(base) The dreynte leandre / for his Erro
(base) The terys of Eleyne / and eke the wo
(base) Of Brixseyde / and of the Ladomea
(base) The crueltee / of the queene Medea
(base) The litel children / hangyng by the hals
(base) For thy Iasoun / that was of loue so fals
(base) O ypermystra / Penolopee / Alceste
(base) Youre wifhod / he comendeth with the beste
(base) But certeinly / no word ne writeth he
(base) Of thilke wikke ensample / of Canacee
(base) That loued / hir owene brother synfully
(base) Of swiche cursed stories / I sey fy
(base) Or ellis / of Tyro Appollonius
(base) How that / the cursed kyng Antiochus
(base) Birafte his doghter / of hir maydenhede
(base) That is / so horrible a tale for to rede
(base) Whan he hir threw / vpon the pauement
(base) And therfore / he of ful auisement

div.l: (base) Nolde neuere write / in noon of his sermons
(base) Of swiche / vnkynde abhominacions
(base) Ne I wol noon reherce / if that I may
(base) But of my tale / how shal I doon this day
(base) Me were looth / be likned doutelees
(base) To Muses / that been clepyd Pierides
(base) Methamorphosios / woot what I mene
(base) But nathelees / I recche noght a bene
(base) Thogh I come after hym / with hawe bake
(base) I speke in prose / and lat hym rymes make
(base) And with that word / he with a sobre cheere
(base) Bigan his tale / as ye shal after heere
(base) ¶ Hic finitr ꝓprologus legis ꝑperiti /

vnto the man of lawe .

IN Flaundres whilom was a companye

Þurgh whiche þei do þe deuel sacrifice

Þat it is grysely for to here hem swere

And eche of hem at other synnes lough

Þat is annexed vn to glotonye
Þe holy writte take I to my witnesse
Þat lechery is in wyne and in dronkenesse
Lo how þat dronken dooth onkyndely

So dronk he was he ne wyste what he wrought

Whan he of wyne was replete at þe feest
