Senek seith one good woord douteles
He seith he can no difference fynde
By twix a man þat is out of his mynde
And a man þat is dronkelewe
But þat wodenesse is fallen in a shrewe
ꝐPerseuꝰeres lengger þanne doth dronkenesse
Of glotonye full of cursednesse
O cause first of our confusiou
O original of oure dampnacou
Thus Criste had brought out hise woordes a yen
Lo how dere and shortly for to seyn
A boute was þe cursed vilanye

Wer dryuen for þat vice it is no drede

He was in paradice and when þat he

O glotonye on the weel ought vs pleyne

A lecherous thyng is wyne and dronkenesse

O . dronken man disfigured is thy face

He can no counsel kepe it is no drede
Now kepe you fro the white and fro the Rede

Þat is to selle in Fissh strete and in chepe

And þanne wole þei seye Sampsou Sampsou
But herkeneth lordynggꝭes I you preye
Þat all þe souꝰereyn actes I dar weel seye

Þat þurgh the verray god omipotente

Bledyng ay at his nose in dronkenesse

And ouꝰere all þis auyse you right weel
What was comanded vn to lamuel

No more of this for it may weel suffice
and now that I s haue spoken of glotonye
Now wole I defende you of hazardrye

may counsell you þe more suerly

¶ Dame qd Melebius
dooth youre wille and your likyng

For I putte me holly
in youre disposicou and ordynaunce

¶ Thanne dame pru-
dence whanne she sawe þe good wil of hir husbonde she
toke a delibacou and aduyce in hir self

thynkyng how she
myght bryng þis nede vn to a gode conclusiou and to a
good ende /

And when she saugh hir tyme She sente for
these aduꝰersaries to come vn to hir to a pryvy place

and
shewed wisely vn to hem þe grete godenesse þat cometh
of pees
and þe grete harmes and ꝑperiles þat ben in werre

And saide to hem in a godely maner / how þat hem aught
haue grete repentaūnce

of Iniurye and wrong þat þei
hadde done to Melebee hir lorde and vn to her doughter

And whenne they herde the godely woordes of dame
prudence /

þei were so supprised and rauasshed and
hadden so grete ioye of hir þat wondre was to telle

A lady qd they / ye haue shewed vn to vs the blissyng
of swetnesse dauid þe ꝓprophe

For þe reconsilyng whiche
we be nat worthy to haue in no maner /

But we aught
requiren it wtith grete contricou and humilite /

ye of yorure
grete godenesse haue presented vn to vs

Now we
see weel þat þe science and þe konyng of Senec is
full true //

For he seith þat swete woordes multiplien
and encresen frendes and maken shrewes to be bonorur
and meke //

Certes qd thei we putte oure dede and all
oure mater and cause all holly in youre gode wille

and ben redy to obeye to þe speche and comaūndement
of my lord Melebee //

And þerfore dere and benigne
lady we praye and byseke you as mekely as we can
and may

þat it like vn to your grete godenesse to ful-
fille in dede youre godely woordes /

For we concidren
and knowleche þat we haue offended and greued my
lord Melebee out of mesure /

So fer forth þat we be
nat of power to make his amendes /

And þerfore
we oblige and bynde vs and oure frendes to do all
his wille and comaūndementes /

But ꝓpro auentre he hath
suche heuynesse and suche wrathe vn to vs warde
by cause of oure offence

þat he wole enioyne vs
suche peyne as we may nat bere ne susteigne

And þerfore noble lady we beseke to youre womanly
pete

to take suche aduysement in this nede þat we
ne oure frendes be nat disherited ne distroyed þurgh
oure folye

Certes qd prudence It is an harde þing
and right perelous

þat a man put hym all vtterly
in the arbitracou and iugemente and in the myght
and power of hise ennemyes

For Senec seith by
leveth it and yeve credence to þat þat I shall seye
I seye qd he yeve nat þe peple and þe gouꝰernours
of holy cherche ne

to þi sone to þi wife and thyne
frende

ne to thy brother neuer þe myght and the
maistrye of thy body while þu lyuest /

Now sithen
he defendeth þat man shuld nat yeve his brother
ne to his frende þe myght of his body /

By a strengger
reson he defendeth and forbedith a man to yeve hym
self to his Ennemye

And nerthelesse I counsell you
þat ye mys truste nat my lorde /

For I wote weel
and knowe verrely þat he debonaire and meke large
curteis

and no thyng desirous ne couetous of goode
ne richesse /

For þere nys no thyng in this worlde þat
he desireth sauf onely worship and honorure //

Forthermore
I knowe weel and I am right sure þat he ne wil no
thyng do in this nede with oute counsell of me

and
I shal so werken in þis cause þat by þe garace of oure lord
god ye shall be reconsiled vn to vs

Thenne seid
thei with one vois // worshipfull lady we putte vs
and oure godes fully in yorure wille and disposicou

and ben redy to come what daye þat it like vn to
youre noblesse to lymyte vs or to assigne vs

for to ma-
ken oure obligacou and bonde as strong as it liketh
to youre godenesse

þat we may fulfille the wille of
you and my lord Melebee .

Whenne dame pudence
hadde herde þe answeres of these men She badde hēm
gone a gayne pryuely

and she retorned to hir lord
Melebee And tolde hym þat she fonde his aduꝰersaries
full repentaūnt

knoulechyng full lowly her synnes
and trespaces and how they were redy to suffren all
peyne
requiryng and praying hym of mcy and pete

Thanne seid Melebius he is weel worthy to haue
pardon and forgevenesse of his synne þat excuseth
nat his synne /

but knoulegeth is and repentith it
askyng indulgence

For Senec seith there is the
remyssion and foryevenesse where as þe confession
is
For confession is neighborur to Innocence

And he
seith in an other place þat he hath shame of his
synne þat knoulegeth it And þerfore I assent and
conforme me to haue pees

But it is gode þat we
do it nat with oute assente and wille of oure
frendes

Thanne was prudence right glad and
ioyefull and seide

Certes ꝸ qd she ye haue wele
and godely answered /

For right as by þe counsell
assente and helpe of youre frendes ye haue be
stired to venge you and make werre

Right soo
with oute her counsell shal nat accorde you ne
haue pees with youre aduersaries //

For þe lawe
seith þer nys no thyng so gode by weye of kynde
as þing to be on bounde by hym þat was y bounde

And þenne dame prudence with oute delay or
tarying sente a none Massengers for hir / kynne
and for hir olde frendes whiche þat were true
and wise

and tolde hem by ordre in the presence
of Melebee all þis mater as it is a boue expres-
sed and declared

and preyed hem þat they wolde
yeuen her aduyse and counsel what best wer
to do in this nede

And whenne Melebius frendes
hadde taken her aduyce and delibacou of the
forseid mater

and hadde examyned it by grete
examynacou and besynesse with diligence /

þei
yaf full counsell for to haue pees and reste .

And þat Melebius shuld receyue wtith good herte
his aduꝰersaryes to foryefunesse and mcy

And whene
dame prudence hadde herde þe assent of hir
lord Melebius and þe counsel of his frendes
accorded with his wille and hir also /

She was
wondre gladde in herte and saide

þer is one
olde ꝓprouerbe qd she That þe godenesse þat þow
maist doo þis daye do it /

and abyde nat to delay
it til to morwe

And þerfore I counsell þat ye
sende your Massangers whiche þat ben discrete
and wise

vn to youre aduꝰersaries / tellyng hem
on youre byhalve

þat if they wole trete of pees
and of accorde

þat þei shapen hem wtith out delaye
or tarying to come vn to vs /

whiche þing was ꝑperfor-
med in dede /

And whenne þese trespasours and
repentyng folk / of her folies þat is to seyne þe aduꝰer-
saries of Melebee

hadde herde what þe Massengers
seiden vn to hem

thei were right gladde and ioye-
full and answered full mekely and benignelye

yeldyng garaces and þankes vn to þer lord Melebee
and all his Companye

And shopen hem wtith oute
delaye to goo wtith þe Massengers and to obeye to þe
comaundement of her lord Melebee //

And right a
Noone they toke her weye to þe courte of Melebee

And toke hem sone of her true frendes to make to
faithe hem and to be her borwes

And whenne
they were I come to þe presence of Melebius
he saide to hem these woordes

It standeth þus
qd Melebius and sooth it is þat ye

causoles and
wtith oute skille or resou

haue do grete Iniuries
and wrong to me And to my wyfe prudence
and to my douter And also

for ye haue entred
in to myne hous by violence

And haue doo suche
outrage þat alle men knowe weel þat ye haue
deꝸued þe deth //

And þerfore wole I knowe and
wite of you

whether ye wole putte þe punysh-
mente and þe chastisement and þe vengeaunce
of þis outrage in the wille of me and of my
wife dame prudence or ye wole nat

þanne
þe wisest of hem alle answered for hem alle and
saide

Sir qd he we knowe weel þat we been
vn worthy to come in to þe courte of so grete a lorde
and so worthy as ye bee /

For we haue so gretely mys-
take vs and haue offended and greved in suche a
wise a geyne your high lordship

þat truly we
haue deꝸued þe deth

But ye for þe grete godenes
and debonaire þat alle þe worlde witnesseth of
youre ꝑpersone /

We submytte vs to youre excellence
and benignite of youre gracous lordship

and be
redy to obeye to alle youre comaundementis /

Byse-
chyng you þat of your mciable pete ye wolde
concidre oure grete repentaūnce and lowe sub-
myssiou

and graunte vs forgefnesse of oure out-
rageous trespaces and offenses

For weel we wote
þat your liberal garace and mcy stretcheth ferther
in to godenesse þanne done oure outrageous gyltes
and trespaces in to wikkednesse //

All be it soo
þat cursedly and dampnably we haue a guylte
a gayne your high lordship

Thanne Melebee
toke hem vp fro þe grounde full benignely

and
resoned her obligacioūns and her bondes by here
othes vpon her plegges and borwes

And assigned
hem a certayn daye to retorne in to his contre

for to
accepte and receyue the sentence and Iugemente þat
Melebee wolde comanunde to be done on hem by these
causes foreseide /

whiche þing ordeyned / euꝰery man retor-
ned home in to his hous /

and whanne þat dame pru-
dence say hir tyme She feyned and axed hir lorde
Melebee /

what vengeaūnce he þought to take on hise
aduꝰersaries /

To whiche Melebee answered and saide
Certes qd he I thynke and purpose me fully

to disherite
hem of all þat þei haue and for to putte hem in exile
for euꝰere

Certes qd dame prudence þis were a cruell
sentence and mochel a geyn reson /

For ye be riche y nough
and haue non nede of noon other mennes gode /

And ye
myght lightly gete you a couetous name

whiche is a vici-
ous þing and ought to be eschewed in euꝰery man

For after
þe woord of þe aple Couetise is rote of alle harmes /

And
þerfor it were better for you to lese so mochel good of yorur
owne þanne for to take of þer gode in this mane

For
better it is to lose good wtith worship þanne to wynne
good wtith vilanye and shame

And euꝰery man ought to doo
his diligence and his besynesse to gete hym a good name
And shal he nat onely be besy in kepyng of his good name

But he shal also enforcen hym Alwey to done thyng þe
whiche may renouele his good name //

For it is y writen
þat þe olde good loos or good name of a man is sone y
done or gone and passed whanne it is nat y newed ne re-
nouelled /

And as touchyng þat ye sayn ye wole exile
your aduꝰersaries

þat þinketh me moche a geyn reson and
oute of mesure

Concideryng þe power þat þei haue yeuen
you vpon hem self

And it is writen þat he is worthy
to lese his piriuilege þat mys vseth þe myght and þe pow-
er þat is yeuen hym

And I sette caas ye myght enioyne
hem þat peyne by right and lawe

whiche I trowe ye
may nat done /

I seye ye myght nat putte it to execucoūn
ꝑperauentre

And þenne wer it likely to retorne to werre
as it was by forne

And þerfore if ye wole þat men
do you obeisaūnce ye must doo more curteisly /

þat is to
sayne ye must yeve more esy sentences and iugementis

For it is writen þat he þat moost curteisly comaūndeth
to hym men moost obeyen /

And þerfor I praye you þat
in þis necessite and in þis nede þat ye caste you to ouer-
come your herte

For Senec seith he þat ouer cometh
his herte ouer cometh twyes

And Tullius seith þere
is no þing so comendable in a grete lorde

as whenne he is
debonaire and meke and apeseth hym lightely

And I paray
you þat ye wole forbere now to done vengeaūnnce

in suche
a mane þat youre good name may be kepte and conꝸued

And þat men may haue cause and mater to prayse you
of pete and of mercy

And þat ye haue no cause to repēmte
you of þing þat ye done

For Senec seith he ouꝰercometh
in an euel mane þat repenteth hym of his victorie /

wher-
fore I paray you lete mcy be in yourer herte

to þe effecte and entente
þat allmyghty god haue mcy on you in his last iugemente

For seynt Iame seith in his Eple / Iugement wtithout mcy
shal be to hym þat hath no mercy

Whanne Melebee hadde
herde the grete skylles and resons of dame prudence
and hir wise enformacoūns and techyngges /

his hte
gan to enclyne to þe wille of his wife concideryng
hir true entente /

Conformed hym a noone and cōm-
sented fully werken after hir counsell

and
þanked god of whom ꝓprocedeth all godenesse þat
hym sente a wife of so grete discresou

And whān
þe daye come þat his aduꝰersaries shuld appere in
his presence

he spake to hem full godely and seid
in this wise

All be it so þat of youre pride
and high presumpcou and folye of yorur necligence
and vnkonnyng

ye haue mysse borne you and trespa-
sed vn to me /

yet for as moche as I see and byholde
youre grete humilite

and þat ye be sory and repen-
taūnt of yorur guyltes /

It constreyneth me to do mcy
and garace /
Wherfore I receyue you to my garace

and for-
yef you vtterly alle þe offenses Iniuries and wron-
gges þat ye haue done a yenst me and myne

to
þis effecte and to this ende / þat god of his endeles
mcy

wole at tyme of oure deying for yef vs oure
guyltes þat we haue trespaced to hym in this
wretched worlde /

For douteles if we be sory and
repentaūnt of þe synnes and guyltes whiche we
haue done in þe sight of our lord god /

he is so fre
in mciable
þat he wole foryeve vs oure guyltes

and bryng vs to þe blysse þat neuꝰer hath ende
Amen

div.l: Whanne ended was þe tale of Mellibe
And of prudence and of her benignite
Our Ooste saide as I am synfull man
And by þe precious Corpus madryan
I had leuꝰere thanne a barelle ale
Þat good lief my wyfe had herde þis tale
A pore widowe somdel stoupe in age
Was whilom duellyng in a narwe Cotage
Biside a Grove duellyng in a dale
This widewe of whom I telle my tale
Sithen thilke daye she was a wife
In pacience hadde a full symple lyfe
For litel was hir Catel and hir Rente
By husbondry of suche good as god hir sente
She fonde hir self and eke hir douters twoo
Three large sowes hadde she and no moo
Three kyne and a shepe þat hight malle
Full soty was hir boure and eke hir halle
In whiche she ete many a slender mele
Of poynaunt sawce hir nedeth neuꝰer a dele
Noo deynte morsel passed hir throte
Hir diete was accordyng to hir Cote
Replecoūn made hir neuer sike
A Temꝑperate diete was all hir phisike
And excercise was hir hertes suffisaunce
And þe gowte lette hir neuer to daunce
Ne poplexie shente nat hir hede
Ne wyne dranke she noone white no reede
Hir boord was moost ꝸued wtith white and blakke
Milke and broun brede in whiche she fonde no lakke
Seynde bacon and somtyme an ey or tweye
For she was as it were a maner deye
A gardeyn she hadde enclosed all a boute
Of stikkes and a drye diche all with oute
In whiche she hadde a Cokke þat hight Chauntcler
In all þe londe of Crowyng nas his peer
His voice was merier þanne þe mery Orgon
On masse dayes þat in the Chirche goon
Weel sikerer was his crowyng in his lodge
Þanne is a Clokke in an abbey or an Orlodge
By nature he croweth eche asscensioūn
Of Equynoctaile in thilke toun
For whenne degrees xv . were ascendede
Þanne crewe he þat it myght nat ben amended
His Combe was redder þenne þe fyne Corall
And batailled as it were a Castel wall
His bille was blak and as þe Ieete it shoone
Ilike azure was his legges and his toone
His nailes whitter were þanne þe lily floure
And like burnysshed gold was his coloure
This gentel Cokke hadde in his gouꝰernaunce
Seuene hennes to done hym plesaunce
Whiche were susters and hise ꝑperamours
And wonder like to hym as of colours
Of whiche þe fairest hued in hir Cote
Was cleped faire damysele pertelote
Curteys she was discrete and debonaire
And companable and bar hir self so faire
Sithen thilke daye she was vij nyght olde
Þat truly she hath þe herte in holde
Of Chauntcler loken in euꝰery lith
He loued hir so þat weel was hym ther with
But suche a ioye it was to here hem syng
Whanne þat þe bright sonne gan to spryng
In swete accorde my lief is faren in londe
For thilke tyme as I haue vnderstonde
Beestis and birdes coude speke and syng
And so by fel þat in a dawenyng
As Chauntclier a mong his wyves alle
Sat on þe perche þat was in þe halle
And nexte hym sat this faire ꝑpertelote
This Chauntcler gan grone in his throte
As a man þat in his dreeme dretched sore
And whanne þis ꝑpertelote þus herde hym roore
She was a gast and seide herte dere
What eyleth you to grone in þat manere
Ye be a verray sleper Fy for shame
And he answered and seide þus Madame
I praye you þat ye take it nought a grief
By god me thought I was in suche myschief
Right now þat yet myne herte is sore a flight
Now god qd he my swefne a retche a right
And kepe my body oute of foule prisone
Me thought þat I roomed vp and doun
With ynne oure yerde where as I sawe a beeste
Was like an hounde and wolde a made arreste
Vpon my body and wolde haue hadde me deede
His colour was by twen white and rede
And tipped was his taile and vp stode his Eeres
With blak on like þe remenant of his heeres
Hise snoute smal with glowyng eyen tweye
Yet for his loke all moost I deye
Þis caused me my gronyng doutelees
A Fy qd she fy on you herteles
Allas qd she for by god a bove
Now haue ye loste myne herte and my love
I can nat love a Coward by my feith
For Certes what so any woman seith
We alle desire if it may bee
To haue husbondes wise hardy and free
And secrete ne noon nygarde ne foole
Ne hym þat is a gaste of euꝰery tole
Ne none auauntorur by þat god a bove
How ye durst ye seye for shame to your love
Þat any þing myght make you a ferde
Haue ye no mannes herte and han a berde
Allas and can ye be agaste of swefenes
No thyng god wote but vanite in swefene is
Swefenes engendren of replexioūns
And ofte of fume and of Complexioūns
Whanne humorurs ben to abundaunt in a wight
Certis þis dreeme whiche ye haue mette þis nyght
Cometh of grete suꝑperfluite
Of your grete colerike ꝑper dee
Whiche causeth folke to dreden in her dreemes
Of arwes and of feer wtith reed beemes
Of reed beestis þat þei wolde hym byte
Of contek and of whelpes grete and lyte
Right as þe humorur of malencolye
Causeth many man in his sleepe crye
For feer of beeres or of boles blake
Or elles blake deueles wole hym take
Of other humorurs coude I telle also
That werken many man in slepe grete woo
But I wole passe as lightly as I can
Loo Caton whiche was so wise a man
Seide he nat þus doo ye no force of dreemes
Now ꝸ qd she / whanne we fle fro these beemes
For goddes love as taketh som laxatyfe
Vp on ꝑperile of my soule and of my lyfe
I counsell you þe beste I wole nat lye
Ye be of Colerike and of malencolye
Yaa purge you and for ye shal nat tarye
Þough in þis toun is noone potecarye
I shall my self ij herbes telle yow
Þat shall be for your heele and for yorur prowe /
And in your gardeyn thoo herbes shal ye fynde
Þe whiche haue of her ꝓpropretes the kynde
To purge you by nethe and eke a bove
Foryete nat þis for goddes owne love
Ye be ful Colerike of Complexiou
Whanne þe sonne is in his ascensiou
Ne fynde you replete of humorurs hoote
And if he doo I dar weel leye a grote
Þat ye shal haue a feuer tercian
Or an ague þat may be youre bane
A daye or ij ye shal haue digestyves
Of wormes er ye take your laxatyves
Of laureal centore and of fumeteer
Or elles of Eleber þat groweth there
Of quater puce or of gaytres beryes
Of herbe yvy growyng in yorur gardyn þer mery is
Pike hem right vp as þei growe and ete hem ynne
Bi mery husbonde for yorur Fadre kyn
Drede no dreem I can sey you no moore
Madame qd he graunt mercy for your loore
But nerthelesse as touchyng Daun Catou
That hath of wisdome suche a grete renoun
By god men may in olde bokes Rede
Though þat he badde no dremes for to drede
Of many a man moore of auctorite
Thanne euer Caton was so mote I the
That alle þe reuꝰerse seyn of his sentence
And haue weel founden by experience
That dremes be significacoūns
As weel of ioye as of Tribulacous
That folke enduren in this lyfe presente
There nedeth to make of þis noone argumente
The verray preef sheweth it in dede
One of þe grettest auctorur þat men may Rede
Saith þus þat twoo felawes wente
On pilgrymage in a full gode entente
And happed so þei come in to a toun
Where as þꝰere was suche a congregacou
Of peple and eke of streight herbigage
Þat þei founde nat as moche as a Cotage
In whiche þei myghte bothe y lodged be
Wherfore they must of necessite
As for þat nyght departen compaignye
And eche of hem goth to his hostelrye
And toke his lodgyng as it wolde by falle
Þe one of hem was lodged in a stalle
Fer in þe yerde with oxen in þe plough
The other man was lodged weel y nough
As was hise auentre or his fortune
That vs alle gouꝰerneth as in comune
And so it be fele long er it was daye
This man mette in his dreeme as he laye
How þat his felawe gan vp on hym calle
And seide allas For in an Oxe stalle
This nyght I shal be murdrede as I lye
Now helpe dere brother or I deye
In all haste come to me he saide
This man out of his slepe for feer he braide
But when þtat he was waked oute of his sleepe
He torned hym and toke of þis noo kepe
Hym þought his dreeme nas but a vanite
Þus twyes in his sleepe dremed he
And at þe iijde tyme yet his felawe
Cam as hym þought / I am now slawe
By holde my body wounded depe and wide
A ryse vp erly in þe morwen tyde
And at þe west gate of þe toun qd he
A Carte full of donge þere shal þou see
In whiche my body is hide full pryuely
Doo thilke Carte arreste boldely
My golde caused my mordre sooth to seyne
And tolde euꝰery poynte how he was slayne
With a ful petous face pale of hewe
And truste weel his dreeme he saide ful true
For on þe morwe as sone as it was daye
To his felawes ynne he toke þe waye
And when þtat he come to þis Oxe stalle
After his felawe he gan to Calle
The hosteler answered hym a noone
And seide ꝸ youre felawe is goone
As sone as daye he wente oute of toun
This man gan a noone falle in suspeccou
Remembryng of his dreeme þat he mette
And forth he goth no lengger wolde he lette
Vn to þe west gate of þe toun and þꝰere he fonde
A donge Carte þat wente as it were to dong londe
That was arraied in þe same wise
As he herde þe deed man deuyse
And wtith an hardy herte he gan to crye
Vengeaūnce and iustice of this felonye
My felawe mordred is this same nyght
And in þis Carte he lithe gapyng vp right
I Crye vp Munistres qd hee
Þat shuld rule and kepe þis Cite
Harrowe allas here lithe my felawe slayn
What shal I more vn to þis sayn
Þe peple vp sterte and caste þe carte to grounde
And in þe mydle of þe dungge þei founde
Þis deed man þat mordred was all newe
O blisfull god þat arte iuste and trewe
Loo how þu bewrayest mordre all waye
Mordre wole out þat see we daye by daye
Murdre is all waltsome and all abhomynable
To god þat is so iuste and resonable
Þat he wole nat suffre it heled be
Þough it a byde a yeer ij or three
Murdre wole out þat is my conclusiou
And right a none Ministres of þe toun
Haue hente þe Carter and sore hym pynede
And eke þe hosteler so sore engynede
Þat þei by knowe þer wikkednesse a noone
And were hangged by þe nekke boone
Here may men see þat dremes be to drede
And Certes in þe same boke I rede
Right in þe nexte Chapetre after this
I gabbe nat / So haue I ioye or blysse
Twoo men þat wolde haue passed ouer þe see
For certeyn cause in to a fer Contre
Yf þat þe wynde ne hadde be contrarye
Þat made hem in a Cite for to tarye
That stode full mery vpon an hauene side
But one daye a yenst þe eve tyde
The wynde gan chaunge and blew as hym leste
Ioly and glade þei wenten vn to reste
And casten hem full Erely for to seyle
A But herkne how a man fele in grete perele
Þat one of hem in slepyng as he laye
Hym mette a wondre dreeme a gayn þe daye
Hym þought a man stode by his bedde side
And hym comaunded þat he shuld abyde
And saide hym þus if þou to morwe wende
Þou shal be dreynte my tale is at an ende
He woke and tolde his felawes what he mette
And prayed hym hem his viage for to lette
As for þat daye he prayed for to abide
His felawe þat lay by his beddes side
Gan for to laugh and scorned hym full faste
Noo dreeme qd he may so myne herte a gaaste
Þat I wole lette for to doo my thyngges
I sette nat a strawe by thy dremyngges
For swefenes ben but vanites and Iapes
Men dreme all daye of Oules and Apes
And of many a Maze ther with all
Men dreme þingges þtat neuꝰer was ne neuꝰer shall
But sithe I see þtat þu wilte here abide
And þus forslouthen wilfully thy tyde
God wote it reweth me and haue good daye
And þus he toke his leve and wente his waye
But er þat he half his cours hadde y seyled
Not I nat why ne what myschaunce it eyled
But casualy þe shippes botme it rente
And ship and man vnder þe water wente
In sight of other shippes hym be syde
Þat wtith hym sailed at þe same tyde
And þerfore faire ꝑpertelote so dere
By suche exaumples olde maiste þu lere
Þat no man shuld be to rechelees
Of dreemes for I saye þe doutelees
Þat many a dreeme full soore is for to drede
Loo in þe lyfe of seynt kenelme I rede
Þat was kenelphus sone þe noble kyng
Of mcnrike how kenelme mette a þing
A litel er he was mordred on a daye
His mordre in hise visiou he saye
His noryce hym expouned euery deel
Hys swefne and for to kepe hym weel
Fro tresou but he was but vij yeer olde
And þerfore litel tale hath he tolde
Of eny dreem so holly was his herte
By god I hadde leuer þanne my sherte
Þat he hadde reedde his legende as haue I
Dame ꝑpertelote I say you truly
Macrobeus þat writeth þe Avisiou
In Affike Affrike with þe worthy Cipriou
Affermeth dreemes and seith þat þei been
Warnyng of þingges þtat men after seen
And ferthermoore I paray you loke weel
The olde testamente of Danyell
Yf ye holde dreemes any vanite
Rede eke of Ioseph and þꝰere shull ye see
Wheþꝰer dreemes ben somtyme I sey nall nat alle
Warnyng of þingges þtat shal after falle
Loke of Egipte þe kyng daun pharaoo
His baker and eke his boteler also
Wheþer þei ne felte none effecte in dremes
Who so wole seke Otty of sondry Realmes
May Rede of dreemes many a wondre þing
Loo Cresus þe whiche was of lide kyng
Mette he nat þat he satte vp on a tree
Whiche signified he shuld an hangged be
Loo here Andromorcha Ectores wife
Þat daye þtat Ector shuld lose his lyfe
She dreemed on þe same nyght by forne
How þtat þe lyfe of Ector shuld be lorne
If thilk daye he were hente in bataile
She warned hym but it myght nat availe
He wente for to fight nerthelesse
And he was slayn of one Achilles
But thilke tale is long to telle
And it is neer daye I may no lengger duelle
Truly I seye as for Conclusiou
Þat I shal haue of þis Avisiou
Aduꝰersitees and I ferther seye moore
Þat I ne telle of laxatyfe noo stoore
For þei be venenous I wote it weel
I hem defye I loue hem neuer a deel
Now lete vs speke of merthe and leeve all þis
Madame ꝑpertelote so haue I blisse
Of one þing god sente me hath large garace
For whanne I see þe beaute of your faire face
Ye been so scarlet reed a boute your eyen
It maketh all my drede for to deyen
For as siker as In principio
Mulier est hōmis Confusio
Madame þe sentence of þis latyn is
Woman is mannes ioye and his blys
For whanne I fele a nyght your softe side
All be it þat I may nat on you ride
For þat your ꝑperche is maked narwe allas
I am so full of Ioye and of solace
That I defye bothe swefne and dreem
And wtith þat woord he flye doun fro þe beem
For it was daye and eke his hennes alle
And with a clokkyng he gan hem calle
For he hadde founde a corne lye in þe yerde
Ryall he was and no more a ferde
He fithered ꝑpertelote xxtiri tyme
And trade as ofte er it were pryme
He loketh as it were a grymme leou
And on his toes he loked vp and doun
Hym deynes nat to sette his feet to grounde
And clokketh whan he hath a corne y founde
And to hym þanne ranne his wifes alle
Þus ryal as a prynce in hise halle
Leve I þis Chauntcler in his pasture
And afer wole I telle his auenture
Whenne þe moneth in whiche þe world bygan
Þat hight Marche whenne god made first man
Was complete and passed were also
Sithe Marche by gan xxtiri dayes and twoo
Byfele þat Chauntcler in all his pride
Hise vij wyves walkyng by his side
Caste vp his eyen to þe bright sonne
Þat in signe of Taurus hadde I Ronne
Twenty degrees and one and somdel moore
He knewe by kynde and by subtile loore
Þat his pryme he crewe wtith blisful stevene
Þe sonne he seid is clomben vpon heuene
Twenty degrees and one and more I wisse
Madame ꝑpertelote my worldelous blysse
Herkne þis blisfull birdes how they syng
And see þe fressh floures how þei spryng
Full is myne herte of reuele and of solace
But sothenly hym fele a sorwefull caas
For euꝰere þe latter ende of ioye is woo
God wote þat worldely ioye is sone goo
And if a Rethorike þat can faire endite
In a Cronicle saufly myght he it e write
As for a souꝰeraigne notabilite
Now euꝰery wise man lete hym herkne me
Þis story is also true I vndertake
As is þe booke of launcelot þe lake blake
Þat women helde in grete reuꝰerence
Now wole I torne a geyn to my sentence
A Cole fox full of sleithe and of Iniquite
Þat in þe grove hadde wonned yeres three
By his Imaginacou a forne caste
Þe same nyght þurgh þe hegge braste
In to þe yerde þer Chauntcler the faire
Was wonte and eke his wyfes to repaire
And in a bedde of woortis stille he laye
Till it was passed vndren of þe daye
Waityng hys tyme on Chauncler to falle
As gladly done þese homycides alle
Þat in a waite liggen to mordre men
O fals Mordrer lurkyng in thy den
O now Scariot O now Genylounye
Fals dyssimillorur O grete Symonye
That broughtest Troye all vtterly to sorwe
O Chauntcler a cursed be þat morwe
Þat þu in to þe yerde flye fro þe beemes
Þou were full warned by thy dreemes
Þat þilke daye was ꝑperellous to the
But þat god wole mote nedes be
After þe opynyou of Certeyn Clerkes
Witnesse of hym þat any good Clerke is
Þat in scole is grete altercacou
In this cas and grete disputacou
And hath ben of an hundred thousand men
But I ne can bulte it to þe bren
As can þe holy doctour Augustyn
Or boicy or þe bisshop Bradwyn
Whether þat god fore wetyng
Streyneth me nedely for to do a thyng
Nedely clepe I necessite
Or if þe free choys be garaunted me
To do þat same þing or do it nought
For god wote er I was wrought
Or if þis wetyng streyneth neuꝰer a deel
But by necessite condicionel
I wole nat haue to do of suche matier
My tale is of a Cok as ye may here
That toke his counsel of his wife wtith sorwe
To walke in to þe yerde vpon a morwe
Þat he hadde mette þe dreem þat I you tolde
Womens Counsell ben full often colde
Womens counsell brought vs first to woo
And made Adam fro paradice to goo
There as he was full mery and weel at ease
But for I wole nat women in no þing displese
If I counsell of hem wolde blame
Passe ouꝰere for I seid it in my game
Rede auctours where þei trete of suche matier
And what þei seye of women here
These ben þe bokes woordes and nat myne
I can non harme of no women deuyne
Faire in þe sonde to bathe hir merily
Liggeth pertelote and alle hir sustres by
A yen þe sonne Chauntcler so free
Sang merier þanne þe Mermaide in the see
For Phisiliogus saith witterly
How þat þei synggen full merely
And so by fele how þat he caste his eye
A mong þe woortes vp on a butter flye
He was war of þe fox þat lay full lowe
No thyng luste hym þanne for to crowe
But cryed cu cou Cok Cok and vp he sterte
As a man þat affraied were in his herte
For naturaly a beest desireth to flee
Fro his contrary if he may it see
Þough he neuꝰer erste had seen it wtith his eye
Þis Chauntcler whanne he gan hym espie
He wolde haue fledde / but þe fox a noone
Seide gentle ꝸ whether wole ye goone
Be ye affraied of me þat am your frende
Now Certes I were wers þanne a fende
Yf I to yow wolde harme or vilanye
I am nat come youre counsell to espie
But truly þe cause of my comyng
Was for to herkne how þat ye syng
For truly ye haue as mery a steuene
As any aungel hath þat is in heuene
Þer with ye haue in musike more felyng
Þanne hadde Boyce or any other þat can syng
My lorde youre fadre god his soule blesse
And eke youre moder of hir gentilnesse
Haue in myne hous y been to me grete ease
And Certes ꝸ ful fayn wole I you please
But for men speke of syngyng I wole seye
So mote I weel brouke my eyen tweye
Sauf you I ne herde neuer man syngge
As dide youre fadre in þe morwenyngge
Certes it was of herte all þat he song
And for to make his voice more strong
He wolde so peyne hym þat wtith bothe his eyen
He must wynke so lowde he dide cryen
And stande vpon hise Tiptoon there wtith all
And stretched forth his nekke þat was small
And eke he was of suche discrecou
Þat þere ne was man in the Regiou
Þat hym in his song or wisdom myght passe
A mong his verse / þere was a Cok
For a preestis sone gaf hym a knok
Vpon hise leggis while he was yong and nyce
He made hym for to lose hise benefice
But certeyn the nys noo comꝑperisou
By twix þe wisdom and þe discrecou
Of youre Fader and of his subtilite
Now synggeth sir for seynt Charite
Lete see can ye youre Fader counterfete
Þis Chauncler hise wiengges gan bete
As man þat coude hise tresou nat espie
So was he rauasshed with his flaterye
Allas ye lordes many a fals flaterorur
Is in youre courte and many a lesengoure
To plese you more by my faith
Þanne he þat sothfastnesse to you saith
Redeth Ecclesiastre of flaterye
Be ware ye lordes of her trecherie
This Chauntcler stode high vpon his toes
Stretchyng his nekke and helde hise eyen cloos
And gan to crowe lowde for þe noones
And Daun Russel sterte vp all at ones
And by þe gargate hente Chauntcler
And on his bak to warde þe wode hem bere
For yet was þer no man þat it hym shewed
O desteny þat maiste nat be eschewed
Allas þat Chauntcler fele fro þe beemes
Allas his wife ne þought on dreemes
And on a friday fele all þis myschaunce
O venus þat arte goddes of plesaunce
Sith þat þine ꝸuant was Chauntcler
And in thy ꝸuice dide all his power
More for delite þanne for þe worlde to multiplie
Why woldest þu suffre hym on thy daye to deye
O Gaufrede dere Maister souꝰeraigne
Þat whan þi worthy kyng Richard was slayn
Why ne haddest þu compleyned his deth so soore
Why ne hadde I now thy sentence and thy lore
The friday for to chide as diden ye
For on a friday sothely slayn was he
Thanne wole I shewe yow how þtat I coude pleyne
For Chauntcler love . and for his peyne
Certes suche crye ne lamentacou
As þe ladies made whenne ylyou
And whenne pirous wtith hise streight swerde
Hente kyng Priom by the berde
And slough hym as seith Eneides
Made neuꝰere as þe hennes in þe cloos
Whanne they hadde seen of Chauntcler this sight
But sothenly dame ꝑpertelote shright
Weel louder þanne dide hastrubaldes wife
Whan þat hir husbond hadde loste his life
And þat þe Romaynes hadde brente Cartage
She was so full of torment and of Rage
Þat wilfully in to þe fier she sterte
And brente hir self wtith a stedefast herte
O wofull hennes right so cryed ye
As whenne þat Nero brenned þe Cite
Of Rome / cryed þe Senatours wyves
For þat her husbondes losten her lyves
With outen guylte þis Nero hath hem slayn
Now wole I torne to my tale a gayn
This sely widewe and hir douters twoo
Herden þese hennes crye and maden woo
And out at þe dore sterte they a noone
And sawe þe fox to warde þe wode goone
And bare vpon his bak the Cok a waye
And Cried out harrowe and weel a waye
A hay þe fox and after hym they ranne
And eke with staves many a nother man
Ranne Colle oure dogg Talbot and gerlande
And malkyn with a distaf in hir hande
Ranne Cow and Calf and eke þe wery hogges
So ferde were for berkyng of þe dogges
And showtyng of þe men and women eke
They ronne so hem thought ther herte breke
They yelled as fendes done in helle
The dogges cried as men wolde hem quelle
The gees for feer flowen ouer þe trees
Oute of þe hyves come þe swarme of bees
So hidous was þe noyse a Benedicite
Certes Iak straw and his menye
Ne made neuer showtes half so shrille
Whanne þat they wolde eny flēmmyng kylle
As thilk daye was made vpon the fox
Of bras thei broughten bemes and of box
Of horne and boon in whiche þei blew and pouped
And þer with all þei steked and þei howped
It semed as þat heuene shuld falle
Now gode men herkeneth alle
Loo how fortune turneth sodēmly sothenly
The hope and pride eke of hir ennemy
This Cok þat lay vp on this fox bak
In all hise drede vn to þe fox he spake
And seide ꝸ if þat I were as ye
Yet shuld I sey so wisly god helpe me
Torne a yen ye proude Cherles alle
A verray pestilence vpon you falle
Now am I come to þe wode syde
Magree youre hed þe Cok shal here a byde
The fox answered in feith it shal be done
I wole hym ete in feith and þat a noone
And he spake þat woord all sodenly
This Cok brake fro his mouth all delyuꝰerely
And when þe fox sawe þat he was goone
And high vp on a tree he flye a noone
Allas qd he a Chauntcler allas
I haue to you qd he done a trespas
In as moche as I maked you a ferde
Whenne I you hente and brought you to this yerde
But ꝸ I dede it nat to no wikked entente
Come a doun and I shal telle you what I mente
I shal seye soth to you god helpe me soo
Nay thanne qd he I shrewe vs bothe twoo
And first I shrewe my self bothe blode and bones
If þou beguyle me eny ofter thenne ones
Thou shalt nomore with thy flatery
Doo me to syng and wynke with myne eye
For he þat wynketh whanne þtat he shuld see
All wilfully / god late hym neuer the
Nay qd the fox god yeve hym moche myschaunce
That is so indiscrete of gouernaunce
That ianggeleth whanne he shulde holde his pes
Loo suche it is for to be retcheles
And necligente and truste on flaterye
But ye þat holden this tale a folye
As of a fox and a Cokke and of an henne
Taketh the moralite gode men
For seynt poule seith all þat written is
To oure doctryne it is writen y wis
Taketh þe frute and lete þe chaf be stille
Now good god if þat it be thy wille
As seith my lord so make vs alle good men
And bryng vs to the high blisse amen

l.hi:
¶ Here endeth the tale of the Nunes preste
¶ And here begynneth the tale of the doctor
of phisik

div.l: (base) ¶ Here bigynneth the Phisiciens tale
(base) THer was as telleth Titus Liuius
(base) A knyght that called was Virginius
(base) Fulfild of honour and of worthynesse
(base) And strong of freendes and of greet richesse
(base) ¶ This knyght a doghter hadde by his wif
(base) No children hadde he mo in al his lif
(base) Fair was this mayde in excellent beautee
(base) Abouen euery wight that man may see
(base) For Nature hath with souereyn diligence
(base) Yformed hire in so greet excellence
(base) As thogh she wolde seyn lo I nature
(base) Thus kan I forme and peynte a creature
(base) Whan that me list who kan me countrefete
(base) Pigmalion noght thogh he ay forge and bete
(base) Or graue or peynte for I dar wel seyn
(base) Apelles zanzis sholde werche in veyn
(base) Outher to graue or peynte or forge or bete
(base) If they presumeden me to countrefete
(base) For he that is the formere principal
(base) Hath maked me his vicaire general
(base) To forme and peynten erthely creaturis
(base) Right as me list and ech thyng in my cure is
(base) Vnder the Moone that may wane and waxe
(base) And for my werk right no thyng wol I axe
(base) My lord and I been ful of oon acord
div.note: Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.
div.l: (base) I made hire to the worship of my lord
(base) So do I alle myne othere creatures
(base) What colour that they han or what figures
(base) Thus semeth me that nature wolde seye
(base) This mayde of age twelue yeer was and tweye
(base) In which that nature hadde swich delit
(base) For right as she kan peynte a lilye whit
(base) And reed a Rose right with swich peynture
(base) She peynted hath this noble creature
(base) Er she were born vpon hir lymes free
(base) Wher as by right swiche colours sholden be
(base) And Phebus dyed hath hir tresses grete
(base) Lyk to the stremys of his burned hete
(base) And if that excellent was hir beautee
(base) A thousand fold moore vertuous was she
(base) In hire ne lakked no condicioun
(base) That is to preyse as by discrecioun
(base) As wel in goost as body chaast was she
(base) For which she floured in virginitee
(base) With all humilitee and abstinence
(base) With all atemperance and pacience
(base) With mesure eek of beryng and array
(base) Discreet she was in answeryng alway
(base) Thogh she were wise Pallas dar I seyn
(base) Hir facound eek ful wommanly and pleyn
(base) No countrefeted termes hadde she
(base) To seme wys but after hir degree
(base) She spak and alle hir wordes moore and lesse
(base) Sownynge in vertu and in gentilesse
(base) Shamefast she was in maydens shamefastnesse
(base) Constant in herte and euere in bisynesse
(base) To dryue hire out of ydel slogardye
(base) Bacus hadde of hir mouth right no maistrye
(base) For wyn and youthe dooth Venus encreesse
(base) As men in fyr wol casten oille or gresse
(base) And of hir owene vertu vnconstreyned
(base) She hath ful ofte tyme syk hir feyned
(base) For that she wolde fleen the compaignye
(base) Where likly was to treten of folye
(base) As is at festes reuels and at daunces
(base) That been occasions of daliaunces
(base) Swich thyng maken children for to be
(base) To soone rype and boold as men may se
(base) Which is ful perilous and hath be yoore
(base) For al to soone may they lerne loore
(base) Which afterward may greve þeim sore
(base) Of boldnesse whan she woxen is a wyf
(base) ¶ And ye Maistresses in youre olde lyf
(base) That lordes doghtres han in gouernance
(base) Ne taketh of my wordes no displesance
(base) Thenketh that ye been set in gouernynges
(base) Of lordes doghtres oonly for two thynges
(base) ¶ Owther for ye han kept youre honestee
(base) Or ellis ye han falle in freletee
(base) And knowen wel ynow the olde daunce
(base) And han forsaken fully swich meschaunce
(base) For euere mo therfore for Cristes sake
(base) To teche hem vertu looke that ye ne slake
(base) Kepeþ wel þo þat ȝe vndertake
(base) ¶ A theef of venyson that hath forlaft
(base) His likerousnesse and al his olde craft
(base) Kan kepe a Forest best of any man
(base) Now kepeth wel for if ye wole ye kan
(base) Looke wel that ye vnto no vice assente
(base) Lest ye be dampned for youre wikke entente
(base) For who so dooth a traytour is certeyn
(base) And taketh kepe of that that I shal seyn
(base) Of alle tresoun souerayn pestilence
(base) Is whan a wight bitrayseth Innocence
(base) ¶ Ye fadres and ye modres eek also
(base) Thogh ye han children be it oon or mo
(base) Youre is the charge of al hir surueaunce
(base) Whil that they been vnder youre gouernaunce
(base) Beth war if by ensample of youre lyuynge
(base) Or by youre necligence in chastisynge
(base) That they perisse for I dar wel seye
(base) If that they doon ye shul it deere abeye
(base) Vnder a Shepherde softe and necligent
(base) The wolf hath many a sheep and lomb to rent
(base) Suffiseth oon ensample now as heere
(base) For I moot turne agayn to my matere
(base) ¶ This mayde of which I wol this tale expresse
(base) So kepte hir self hir neded no maistresse
(base) For in hir lyuyng maydens myghten rede
(base) As in a book euery good word or dede
(base) That longeth to a mayden vertuous
(base) She was so prudent and so bounteuous
(base) For which the fame out sproong on euery syde
(base) Bothe of hir beautee and hir bountee wyde
(base) That thurgh that land they preysed hire echone
(base) That loued vertu saue enuye allone
(base) That sory is of oother mennes wele
(base) And glad is of his sorwe and his vnheele
(base) The doctor maketh this discripcioun
(base) This mayde vpon a day wente in the toun
(base) Toward a temple with hir moder deere
(base) As is of yonge maydens the manere
(base) ¶ Now was ther thanne a Iustice in that toun
(base) That gouernour was of that Regioun
(base) And so bifel this Iuge hise eyen caste
(base) Vpon this mayde auysynge hym ful faste
(base) As she cam forby ther as this Iuge stood
(base) Anoon his herte chaunged and his mood
(base) So was he caught with beautee of this mayde
(base) And to hymself ful pryuely he sayde
(base) This mayde shal by myn for any man
(base) Anon the feend in to his herte ran
(base) And taughte hym sodeynly that he by slyghte
(base) This mayden to his purpos wynne myghte
(base) For certes by no force ne by no meede
(base) Hym thoughte he was nat able for to speede

div.l: (base) For she was strong of freendes and eek she
(base) Confermed was in swich souerayn bountee
(base) That wel he wiste he myghte hir neuere wynne
(base) As for to make hire with hir body synne
(base) For which by greet deliberacioun
(base) He sente after a cherl was in the town
(base) Which that he knew for subtil and for bold
(base) This Iuge vnto this cherl his tale hath told
(base) In secree wise and made hym to ensure
(base) He sholde telle it to no creature
(base) And if he dide he sholde lese his heed
(base) Whan that assented was this cursed reed
(base) Glad was this Iuge and maked hym gret cheere
(base) And yaf hym yiftes preciouse and deere
(base) ¶ Whan shapen was al hir conspiracie
(base) Fro point to point how that his lecherie
(base) Parfourned sholde been ful subtilly
(base) As ye shul heere it after openly
(base) ¶ Hom goth the cherl that highte Claudius
(base) This false Iuge that highte Apius
(base) So was his name for this is no fable
(base) But knowen for historial thyng notable
(base) The sentence of it sooth is out of doute
(base) This false Iuge gooth now faste aboute
(base) To hasten his delit al that he may
(base) And so bifel soone after on a day
(base) This false Iuge as telleth vs the storie
(base) As we fine writen in olde storie
(base) As he was wont sat in his Consistorie
(base) And yaf his domes vpon sondry cas
(base) ¶ This false cherl cam forth a ful gret pas
(base) And seyde lord if that it be youre wille
(base) As dooth me right vpon this pitous bille
(base) In which I pleyne vpon Virginius
(base) And if that he wol seyn it is nat thus
(base) I wol it preue and fynde good witnesse
(base) That sooth is that my bille wol expresse
(base) ¶ This Iuge answerde of this in his absence
(base) I may nat yeue diffynytif sentence
(base) Lat do hym calle and I wol gladly heere
(base) Thow shalt haue al right and no wrong heere
(base) ¶ Virginius cam to wite the Iuges wille
(base) And right anon was rad this cursed bille
(base) The sentence of it was as ye shul heere
(base) ¶ To yow my lord sire Apius so deere
(base) Sheweth youre poure seruant Claudius
(base) How that a knyght called Virginius
(base) Agayns the lawe agayn al equitee
(base) Holdeth expres agayn the wyl of me
(base) My seruant which that is my thral by right
(base) Which fro myn hous was stole vpon a nyght
(base) Whil that she was ful yong this wol I preue
(base) By witnesse lord so that it nat yow greue
(base) She nys his doghter nat what so he seye
(base) Wher to yow my lord the Iuge I preye
(base) Yeld me my thral if that it be youre wille
(base) Lo this was al the sentence of his bille
(base) ¶ Virginius gan vpon the cherl biholde
(base) But hastily er he his tale tolde
(base) And wolde haue proued it as sholde a knyght
(base) And eek by witnessynge of many a wight
(base) That it was fals that seyde his Aduersarie
(base) This cursed Iuge wolde no thyng tarie
(base) Ne here a word moore of Virginius
(base) But yaf his Iuggement and seyde thus
(base) ¶ I deme anon this cherl his seruant haue
(base) Thou shalt no lenger in thyn hous hir saue
(base) Go bryng hir forth and put hire in oure warde
(base) The cherl shal han his thral this I awarde
(base) ¶ And whan this worthy knyght Virginius
(base) Thurgh sentence of this Iustice Apius
(base) Moste by force his deere doghter yeuen
(base) Vnto the Iuge in lecherie to lyuen
(base) He goth hym hom and sette hym in his halle
(base) And leet anoon his deere doghter calle
(base) And with a face deed as asshen colde
(base) Vpon hir humble face he gan biholde
(base) With fadres pitee stikyng thurgh his herte
(base) Al wolde he from his purpos nat conuerte
(base) ¶ Doghter quod he Virginia by thy name
(base) Ther been two weyes outher deeth or shame
(base) That thow most suffre allas that I was bore
(base) For neuere thow deseruedest wherfore
(base) To dyen with a swerd or with a knyf
(base) O deere doghter endere of my lyf
(base) Which I haue fostred vp with swich plesance
(base) That thow were neuere out of my remembrance
(base) O doghter which that art my laste wo
(base) And in my lyf my laste ioye also
(base) O gemme of chastitee in pacience
(base) Tak thow thy deeth for this is my sentence
(base) For loue and nat for hate thow most be deed
(base) My pitous hand moot smyten of thyn heed
(base) Allas that euere Apius thee say
(base) Thus hath he falsly Iugged thee to day
(base) Is there no grace is there no remedie cat
(base) And tolde hire al the cas as ye bifore
(base) Han herd nat nedeth for to telle it moore
(base) ¶ O mercy deere fader quod this mayde
(base) And with that word she bothe hir armes layde
(base) Aboute his nekke as she was wont to do
div.note: Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.
div.l: (base) The teeris borste out of hir eyen two
(base) And seyde goode fader shal I dye
(base) Is ther no grace is ther no remedye
(base) ¶ No certes deere doghter myn quod he
(base) ¶ Thanne yif me leyser fader myn quod she
(base) My deeth for to compleyne a litel space
(base) For pardee Iepte yaf his doghter grace
(base) For to compleyne er he hir slowe allas
(base) And god it woot no thyng was hir trespas
(base) But for she ran hir fader for to se
(base) To wel come hym with greet solempnytee
(base) And with that word she fil aswowne anon
(base) And after whan hir swownyng is agon
(base) She riseth vp and to hir fader sayde
(base) Blessed be god that I shal dye a mayde
(base) Yif me my deeth er that I haue a shame
(base) Dooth with youre child youre wyl a goddes name
(base) And with that word she preyed hym ful ofte
(base) That with his swerd he wolde smyte softe
(base) And with that word aswowne doun she fil
(base) ¶ Hir fader with ful sorweful herte and wil
(base) Hir heed of smoot and by the top it hente
(base) And to the Iuge he gan it to presente
(base) As he sat yet in doom in Consistorie
(base) ¶ And whan the Iuge it saw as seith the storie
(base) He bad to take hym and anhange hym faste
(base) But right anon a thousand peple In thraste
(base) To saue the knyght for routhe and for pitee
(base) For knowen was the false Iniquitee
(base) ¶ The peple anon hadde suspect in this thyng
(base) By manere of the cherles chalangyng
(base) That it was by the assent of Apius
(base) They wisten wel that he was lecherus
(base) For which vnto this Apius they gon
(base) And caste hym in a prison right anon
(base) Ther as he slow hymself and Claudius
(base) That seruant was vnto this Apius
(base) Was demed for to hange vpon a tree
(base) But that Virginius of his pitee
(base) So preyde for hym that he was exiled
(base) And ellis certes he hadde been bigyled
(base) The remenant were anhanged moore and lesse
(base) That were consentant of this cursednesse
(base) ¶ Heere may men seen how synne hath his merite
(base) Beth war for no man woot whom god wol smyte
(base) In no degree ne in which manere wise
(base) The worm of conscience may agrise
(base) Of wikked lyf thogh it so pryuee be
(base) That no man woot ther of but god and he
(base) For be he lewed man or ellis lered
(base) He noot how soone that he shal been afered
(base) Therfore I rede yow this conseil take
(base) Forsaketh synne er synne yow forsake
(base) ¶ Here endeth the Phisiciens tale
Here begynneth the Shipmannes tale
A Marchaunt whilom duelled at seynt denys
That riche was for whiche men helde hym wys
A wife he had of excellente beaute
And compayngnable and reuerent was she
Whiche is a thyng þat causeth more expens
Þat worth is al þe chier and reuꝰerence
That men done at festis or daunces
Suche salutacoūns or countenaūnnces
Passeth as dooth þe shadowe vpon þe wal
But woo is hym þat paye shall for all
The sely husbond algate he must paye
He must vs clothe he must vs arraye
All for his owen worship richely
In whiche array we daunce Iolily
And if þat he may nat ꝑper auentre
Or elles no suche despences endure
But thynketh it is a waste and y loste
Þanne mote a nother paye for oure coste
Or lende vs gold and þat is perelous
Þis noble marchaūnt hilde a noble hous
For whiche he hadde all daye grete repaire
For his largenesse and for his wife was faire
That wondre is but herkenes to my tale
A mong alle guestes grete and smale
There was a monke a faire man and a bolde
I trowe XXXtiri wynter he was olde
Þat euꝰere was drawyng to þat place
This yong monke þat was so faire of face
And quaynted was soo þat þis good man
Sithe þat he first hise knowlege by gan
Þat in his hous as famyliar was he
As it is possible eny frende for to be
And for as moche as this gode man
And eke þis Monke of whiche þat I began
Were bothe two y borne in one village
The monke hym claymeth as for Cosynage
And he a yen he saith nat ones naye
But was als glad ther of as foule of daye
For to his herte it was a grete plesaūnnce
Thus be they knytte with etꝰerne alliaūnce
And ilke of hem gan other to assure
Of brotherhode whiles þer lyves may endure
Free was daun Iohn and manly of dispence
As in þat hous and eke full of diligence
To doo plesaūnnce and also grete Costage
He not foryate to geve the liest page
In all þat hous but after ther degree
He yaf the lord and after alle the menee
Whanne þat he cam som maner honeste thyng
For whiche þei were as glad of his comyng
As foule is fayne whanne sonne vp riseth
Nomore of þis for now it sufficeth
But so byfele þat þis Marchaunt vp on a daye
Shope hym to make hym redy in arraye
To warde þe toun of Bruges for to fare
To byen hym there a porcoūn of good ware
For whiche he hath to Parissh sent a noone
A Massenger and praied hath daun Iohn
Þat he shuld come to seynt Denys and playe
With hym and wtith his wife a daye or twaye
Er he to Bruges wente in any wise
This noble Monke of whiche I you devise
Hath of his Abbot as hym luste licence
By cause he was a man of high prudence
And eke an Officer out for to ride
To see her graunges and eke her biernes wide
And vn to seynt denys he cometh a noone
He was welcome as my lord daun Iohn
O dere Cosyn full of Curtesie
With hym brought a Iugge of maluesye
And eke an other full of fyne vernage
And volatile as ay was his vsage
And þus I lete hem ete and drynke and play
This Marchaūnt and þis Monke a day or tway
The thridde day this Marchaūnnt vp he ryseth
And on his nedys hym sadly aviseth
And vp in to his Countre hous goth he
To rekne with hym self as weel may be
Of thilke yeer how þat it with hym stode
And how þat he dispended hath his good
And if þat he encresed were or noone
His bokes and his bagges many one
He leith by forne hym on his countyng boorde
For riche was his tresore and his hoorde
For whiche full faste his countre dore he shette
And loked þat no man shulde hym lette
Of his accomptes for the meane tyme
And þus he sat til it was passed pryme
Daun Iohn was rysen in þe morwe also
And in þe garden walketh to and fro
And hath his thyngges saide full curteislye
This good wife cam walkyng full pryuelye
In to the gardeyn there he walketh softe
And hym salueth as she hath done ofte
A maide Childe come in hir companye
Whiche as hir luste may gouꝰerne and guye
For yet vnder þe yarde was þe maide
O dere Cosyn myne Daun Iohn she saide
What ailes yow so rathe for to ryse
Nece qd he it aught y now to suffise
Fyve houres for to slepe on nyght
But it were for an h olde palled wight
As ben þese wedded men þat ly and dare
As in a forme sitteth a wery hare
Þat wer all for straugth wtith houndes grete and smale
But dere Nece why be ye so pale
I trowe Certes þat oure gode man
Hath you labored sith þe nyght by gan
Þat you were nede to resten hastely
And wtith þat woord he lough full merily
And of his owne þought he wax all reed
Þis faire wife gan to shake hir heed
And saide þus god wote all qd she
Nay Cosyn myne it standeth nat soo wtith me
For by þat god þtat gaf soule and lyfe
In all þe Realme of Fraūnce is þer no wife
Þat lesse luste hath to þat sory play
For I may syng allas and weel a way
Þat I was borne but no wight qd she
Dar I nat telle how it stante with me
Wherfore I thynke out of þis londe to wende
Or elles of my self to make an ende
So full am I of drede and eke of care
This Monke by gan vp on þis wife to stare
And saide Allas my Nece god forbede
Þat ye for any sorwe or for drede
For do your self but telleth me yorur greef
ꝐPer auentre I may in youre myschief
Counsel or helpe and þerfore telleth me
All your a noye for it shal be secree
For on my portoos I make an othe
Þat neuer in lyve for lief nor lothe
Ne shal I of no counsell you by wraye
Þe same a yen to you qd she I saye
By god and by þis portoos I swere
Þough men me wolde al in to pecis tere
Ne shal I neuꝰere for to goo to helle
By wreye woord of þing men me telle
Nat for no Cosynage ne for none alliaūnnce
But verely for love and affiaūnnce
Thus be thei sworne and here vp on kissed
And ilke of hem tolde other what hem lyste
Cosyn qd she if I hadde a space
As I haue noon and namely in this place
Thenne wolde I telle a legende of my lyfe
What I haue suffred sithe I was wyfe
With myne husbond all þough he be yorur Cosyn
Nay qd þis Monke by god and by seynt Martyn
He is no more Cosyn vn to me
Þanne is þe leef þat hanggeth on þe tree
I clepe hym soo by seynt Denys in Fraūnnce
To haue þe more cause of acqueyntaūnnce
Of you whiche I haue loued specially
A bouen alle women sikerly
This swere I you on my ꝓprofessiou
Telleth youre greef lest þat he come doun
And hasteth you and goo your weye a noone
My dere love qd she O Daun Iohn
Full lief me were þis Counsel to hyde
But oute it mote it may no longger a byde
Myne husbond is to me þe werste man
Þat euer was sithe þe worlde by gan
But sith I am a wife it sitte nat me
To telle no wight of oure preuyte
Neither in bed ne in noone other place
God shelde I shuld telle it for his grace
A wife shuld nat seye of hir husbond
But all honour as I can vnderstonde
Saf vn to you þus moche telle I shal
As helpe me god he is nat worth at all
In no degre þe value of a flye
But yet me greueth moost his nyggardye
And weel ye wote þat women naturaly
Desiren suche thyngges as weel as I
Thei wold þat her husbondes shuld be
Hardy and wise riche and eke Free
And buxom to his wife and fressh in bedde
But by þat lord þat for vs blode bledde
For his honour my self to arraye
A sonday nexte me must paye
An hundred frankes or elles I am lorne
Yet were me leuer þat I were on borne
Þanne me were doone a slaundre or a vilanye
I ne were but loste and þerfore I you preye
Liende me þis sōmme or elles me must deye
Daun Iohn I seye liende me þese hundred frankes
Pardee wole I nat faile you my thankes þankes
If þat you luste to do þat I praye
For at a certeyn daye I wole you paye
And do you what plesaūnnce and ꝸuice
Þat I may do right as you lust deuyse
And but I do god on me take vengeaūnce
As foule as had geneuylion of Fraūnnce
This gentil monke answered in þis maner
Now truly myne owen lady dere
I haue on you so grete a ruthe
Þat I swere to you and plight my truthe
Þat whenne youre husbond is to flaundres fare
I wole delyuꝰere you out of all þis care
For I wole bryng you an hundred frankes
And wtith þat he caught hir by þe flankes
And hir enbraced harde and kissed hir ofte
Goth now your weye qd he all stille and softe
And lete vs dyne as sone as ye may
For by kalendre it is pryme on þe daye
Goth now and be as true as I shal be
Now elles god forbede ꝸ qd she
And forth she goth as iolyfe as a pye
And bad þe Cokes þtat þei shuld hem hye
So þat men myght dyne and þat a noone
Vn to hir husbond is þis wife goon
And knokketh at his countre boldely
Quy la. qd he petre it am I
Qd she what how long wha wole ye faste
How long tyme wole ye rekne and caste
Youre somes youre bokes and youre þingges
The deuel haue parte of alle suche rekenyngges
Ye haue y nough pardee of goddes sonde
Come to daye and lete youre bagges hong
Ne be ye nat a shamed þat daun Iohn
Shall fastyng all þis daye þus elongely goone
Lete vs here masse and goo we dyne
Wife qd þis man litel canst þu deuyne
The curious besynesse þat we haue
For of vs Chapmen so god me saue
And by þat lord þat cleped is seynt yve
Scarsely a mong xij two shul thryve
Contynually lastyng vn to oure age
We may weel make a gode visage
And dryve forth þe worlde as it may be
And kepe oure estate in preuyte
Till we be deede or elles þat we play
A pilgrymage or gone out of þe way
And þerfore haue I grete necessite
Vp on þis queynte worlde to aduyse me
For euer more we mote stonde in drede
Of happe and fortune in oure chapmanhede
To Flaundres wole I goo to morwe at daye
And come a gayn als sone as I maye
For whiche my dere wife I þe beseke
As be to euꝰery wight buxom and meke
And for to kepe oure good be Curious
And honestly gouꝰerne weel oure hous
Þou haf hast y nough in euꝰery maner wise
Þat to a trusty wife may suffise
The lakketh none array ne none vitaile
Of syluer in thy purs þou maist nat faile
And wtith þat woord his Countre dore he on shette
And doun he goth no longger wolde he lette
But hastely a masse was there saide
And spedely þe tables were y laide
And to þe dyner fast þei hem spedde
And richely þe Chapman þe monke fedde
And after dyner daun Iohn sobrely
This Chapman toke a parte preuyly
And saide hym Cosyn þus it standeth soo
Þat weel I see to Bruges wole ye goo
God and seynt Austyn spede you and guyde
I pray you Cosyn wisely þat ye ride
Gouꝰerne you also of youre diete
Attemꝑperly and namely in þis hete
By twen vs twoo nedeth no straunge fare
Fare weel Cosyn God shilde you fro Care
If any thyng be there by day or by nyght
If it lay in my power or in my myght
Þat ye wole comaunde me done in any wise
It shall be done right as ye wole deuyse
O þing er þat ye goone if it may be
I wolde praye you for to lende me
An hundred frankes a daye or tweye
For certeyn bestis þat I must beye
To store with a place þat is oures
God helpe me soo it I wolde it were youres
I shal nat faile suerly at my daye
Nought for a Ml frankes a myle waye
But lete þis thyng be secrete I you praye
For þese bestis þis nyght yet must I paye
And fare now weel my Cosyn dere
Graunt mcy of your coste and of your chere
This noble Marchaunt gently a noone
Answered and saide O Cosyn daun Iohn
Now sekerly is þis a smal requeste
My golde is youre owen when you leste
And nat onely my gold but my chaffare
Take what you luste god shield ye spare
But one thyng as ye knowe it weel y nough
Of Chapmen þat her money is her plough
We may creaunce whiles we haue a name
But goldeles for to be it is no game
Pay it a geyn when it lithe in youre ease
Afor my myght ful fayn wolde I you plese
These C frankes he fette forth a noone
And pryuely he to toke hem to Daun Iohn
Noo wight in all þis worlde wist of þis loone
Sauyng þis Marchaunt and daun Iohn allone
They drynke and spake and ronne a while and play
Till þat daun Iohn rideth vn to his abbaye
The morwe cam and forth þis Marchaunt rideth
To Flaundres warde his appntice wel hym guydeth
Til he come to Bruges murely
Now goth þis Marchaūnnt fast and besily
A boute his nede and beyeth and creaunseth
He nouther pleyeth at þe dyce ne daunseth
But as a marchaunt shortely for to telle
He badde his lyfe and þere I late hym duelle
The sonday next Daun Iohn is goon
To seynt Denys he is come a noon
With Croune and berde all fressh and newe y shave
In all þe house þer nas so litel a knave
Ne no wight elles þtat he ne was full fayn
For þtat my lord daun Iohn was come a gayn
And shortely to her poynte for to goone
This faire wife accordeth with daun Iohn
Þat for þese C frankes he shuld all nyght
Haue hir in hise armes bolte vp right
And þis accorde ꝑperformed was in dede
In myrthe all nyght a besy lyfe thei lede
Til it was daye þat daun Iohn went his waye
And bad þe meny fare wel and haue good daye
For none of hem ne no wight in þe toun
Hath of daun Iohn right non suspeccou
And forth he rideth hom till his Abbeye
Or where hym luste no more of hym I seye
Þis Marchaunt when þtat ended was þe feyre
To seynt Denys he gan to repaire
And wtith his wife he maketh feste and chier
And telleth þat Chaffare is soo dere
Þat nedes must he make a chevesaunce
For he was y bounde in a recognisaunce
To paye XXti thousand shieldes a noon
For whiche þis Marchaunt is to paryssh goon
To borwe of certeyn frendes þat he hadde
A Certeyn Frankes and some wtith hym he ladde
And whanne he was come to þe toun
For grete chier and grete affeccioūn
Vn to daun Iohn he first goth hym to playe
Nought for to borwe of hym no monaye
And for to wete and see of his welfare
And for to telle hym of his Chaffare
As frendes done whan þei be met in fere
Daun Iohn hym maketh feste mid mery chere
And he hym tolde a gayn full specially
How he had bought full weel and garaciously
Thanked be god his marchaundize
Sauf þat he must in all maner wise
Make a chevesaunce as for his beste
And þanne he shulde be in ioye and reste
Daun Iohn answered Certes I am fayn
Þat ye in hele arn comen a gayn
And if þat I were riche as haue I blisse
Of xxtiri thousand shieldes shuld ye nat mysse
For ye so kyndely this other daye
Lente me gold and as I can and may
I thanke you by god and by seynt Iame
But natheles I toke it to oure dame
Your wife at home þe same gold a gayn
By certeyn tokens she wote it weel certayn
Vp on your benche þat I can hir telle
Now by your leve I may no lengger duelle
Oure Abbot wele out of þis toun a noone
And in hise compaygnye must I goone
Grete weel oure dame my nees swete
And fare weel my Cosyn til þtat we mete
Þis Marchaūnt whiche þtat was bothe ware and wise
Creaunced hath and payed eke at parish
To certeyn lumbardes and payed redy in honde
This some of gold and toke of hem his bonde
And home he goth as mery as a popyn Iaye
For weel he knewe he stode in suche arraye
That nedes must he wynne in suche a viage
A Ml frankes by side all his Costage
His wife full redy mette hym at þe gate
As she was wonte of vsage algate
And all þat nyght in merthe þei be sette
For he was riche and clerly out of dette
Whanne it was daye þis Marchaūnt gan ēmbrace
His wife all newe and kissed hir on þe face
And vp he goth and maketh it full tough
Nomore qd she by god ye haue y nough
And wantounely wtith hym she pleyed
Till at þe last þis Marchaunt seide
By god qd he I am a litel wroth
Wtith you my wife all though it be me looth
And wote ye why by god as þat I guesse
Þat ye haue made a maner straungenesse
By twen me and my Cosyn Daun Iohn
Ye shuld haue warned me er I had goon
Þat he you hadde an C frankes y payed
For as me semed he was nat weel y payed
For þat I spake to hym of chevisaunse
Me semed so by hise countenaunce
But nertheles by god heuene kyng
I thought nat to axe hym no thyng
I praye you wife do ye no more soo
Telle me all wey er þtat I fro you goo
Yf any dettorurs haue in myne absence
Y payed to þe aught / for þurgh thyne necligence
I may hym axe a thyng þat is payed
She was nat a ferde ne affrayed
But holly she saide and þat a noone
Mary I defye þat Munke daun Iohn
I kepe nat of his tokenes neuer a deel
He toke me certeyn gold þtat wote I weel
Þat euel deth vpon his monkes snowte
For god it wote I wende wtith oute doute
Þat he had goven it me by cause of yow
To do þꝰer with myne owen ease and myne prow
For Cosynage and eke for beal chier
Þat he hath hadde full ofte tymes here
But sith I stonde in his disioynte
I wole you answere shortely to þe poynte
Sh / ye haue more slakke dettorurs þanne I
For I wole paye you weel and redely
Fro daye to daye and if so be y faile
I am your wife / score it on my taile
And I shal paye it as soone as I may
For by myne trouth I haue on myne array
And nat in waste by stowed it euꝰery deel
And for I haue stowed it so weel
To youre honour / For goddes sake I say
As beth nat wroth but lete vs laugh and play
Ye shall my Ioly body haue to wedde
By god I nyl nought paye you but in bedde
Foryeve it me myne owen spouse dere
Torne hederwarde and make better chere
Þis Marchaūnt þtat þer nas no better remedie
And for to chide it ne were but folye
Sith þtat þe þing may nat amended be
Now wife he saide þanne I foryeve it the
But by thy lyfe be no moore so large
Kepe better my good this gif I the in charge
Thus endeth now my tale and god vs sende
Talkyng y nowgh vn to oure lyves ende
Here endeth the tale of the Maryn
Here begynneth the tale prolog of the Pirierasses ta
WEle y saide by Corps dūns qd oure hooste
Now long mote þou saile by þe cooste
Sir gentle Maister gentil Marynere
God yeve þe Monke a Ml laste of quadeyere
A ha felawes by ware of suche a Iape
Þe Monke put in þe Mannes hode an ape
And his wives eke by seynt Austyn
Drawes noo Munkes moore to youre ynne
But now passe ouer and lete seke a boute
Who shal now telle first of all þis Rowte
An other tale and wtith þat woorde he saide
As Curteysly as it hadde ben a mayde
My lady Prioresse by youre leve
So þat I wiste I shuld you nat greve
I wolde deme þat ye telle shulde
A tale nexte if so were þtat ye wolde
Now wole ye vouchesauf my lady dere
Glady qd she and seid in þis manere

l.hi: Here begynneth the priorasses tale ofAlma Redemptoris

div.l: O lord oure lord þi name how meruelous
Is in þis large worlde spradde qd she
For nought onely thy laude precious
ꝐPerformed is by men of Dignite
But by þe mouthe of Childre þi boūnnte
Performed is on oure breest sowkyng
Some tyme shewe they thyne heryng
Wherfore in laude as I best can or may
Of þe and of thy white lyly floure
Whiche þat þe bare and is a maide alway
To telle a storye I wole do my laboure
Nought þat encres I may your laboure
For she hir self is honour and Rote
Of bounte next hir sone and soules boote
O Moder maide O maide moder free
O bussh on brente brennyng in Moises sight
Þat Raueshediste doune fro the deite
Þurgh thy humblesse þe goste þat in þe light
Of whos vertue whenne he in thyne herte light
Conceyved was þe Fader sapience
Helpe me to telle it in thy Reuerence
Lady thy bounte thyne magnificence
Thy vertue and thy grete humylite
Ther may no tung expresse in noo science
For som tyme lady er men praye to the
Thou gooste by forne of thy benignite
And guetist vs the light of oure prayer
To geten vs to thy sone soo dere
My konyng is to weike o blisfull quene
For to declare thy grete worthynesse
Þat I ne may nat þe with susteyne
But as a Childe xij moneth olde or lesse
Þat can vnnethes any woord expresse
Right so fare I and therfore I you praye
Guideth my song þat I shal of you saye

l.hi: Here folweth the tale of the seid priorasseto a conclusion

div.l: There was in Asye in a grete Cite
A mong Cristen folke a Iurye
Susteyned by a lord of þat Contre
Suche maner doctryne as men vse there
For foule vsure and lucre of vilanye
Hatefull to Criste and to his companye
And þurgh þe strete ride or wende .
For it and open at euery
A litel scole of Cristen folke there stode
Doun at ferther ende in whiche there were
Children an heep / y come of Cristes bloode
Þat lerned in þat scole yere by yere
Suche maner doctryne as men vse there
This is to seye to syng and eke to rede
As smale Children done in her Childehede
A mong these Children was a widewes sone
A litel Clergion þat vij yeer was of age
That daye by daye to scole was his wone
And eke also where so he saugh þe ymage
Of Cristes moder / hadde he eke the vsage
As hym was taught to knele a doun and say
His Aue Maria as he goth by the waye
Thus hath þis widewe hir litel Childe y taught
Oure blisfull lady Cristes moder dere
To worship ay / he forgete it naught
For Sely Childe wolde alwey sone lere
But ay whenne I remembre of þis matere
Seynt Nicholas stante euer in my presence
For he to Criste so yong dide reuerence
This litel Childe his litel boke lernyng
As he sat in þe scole at his prymer
He Alma Redemptoris herde syng
As Children lerned her antiphoner
And as he durste he drough hym ner and nere
And herkened ay þe woordes and þe note
Till he þe firste verse coude all by Rote
Nat wiste he what þis latyn was to saye
For he was yong and tendre eke of age
But on a daye his felawe gan he praye
To expoune hym þis song in his langage
Or telle hym why þis song was in vsage
This preyed he hym to construe and declare
Full often tymes vp on his knees bare
His felawe whiche þat was older þanne he
Answered hym þus þis song I haue herde say
Was made for oure lady blisful lady free
Hir to salue and eke hir to praye
To ben oure helpe and oure socorur whanne we deye
I can no more expoune in this matier
I lere syngg I can no more gramer
And is this song made in reuꝰerence
Of Cristes moder seide this Innocente
Now Certes I wole do my diligence
To knowe it all er Cristemasse be wente
Though I for my premer shule be sente
And shuld be beten thries in an houre
I wole it konne oure lady to honoure
His felawe taught hym homward pryuyely
Fro daye to daye til he coude it by Rote
And þanne he lerned it weel and boldely
Fro woorde to woord till accordyng to þe Note
Twyes on þe daye it passed þurgh his throte
To scole warde and homwarde whenne he wente
On Cristes moder sette he all his entente
As I haue seide þurgh out the Iurye
This litel Childe as he come to and froo
Full merely þanne wolde he syng and crye
O alma Redemptoris euer moo
The swetnesse hath his herte perced soo
Of Cristes moder / þat to hir to praye
He can nat stynte of syngyng by þe waye
Oure first Foo þe serpent Sathanas
Þat hath in Iewes herte his waspes neste
Vp swelled and seid O . hebreak peple allas
Is þis a thyng to you þat is honeste
Þat suche a boy shall walke as hym leste
In your dete and syng of suche sentence
Whiche is a yenste youre lawes reuꝰerence
Fro thens þe Iewes haue conspired
Þis Innocente out of þis worlde to enchace
An homycide therto haue they hyred
Þat lay in a waite in a preuy place
And as this Childe gan forth by to pace
Þis fals Iewe hym hente and helde hym faste
And kytte his throte and drough hym at þe laste
I saye þtat in a wardrope þei hym threwe
Where as þese Iewes th purgen ther entraile
O cursed folk O herodes all newe
What may youre euel entent you aduaile
Murdre wole oute certeynly it wole nat faile
And namely þere þe honorur of god shuld sprede
Þe blood out crieth on youre cursed dede
O Martir sounded to virginite
Now maist þou syng folwyng euer in oone
The whight lambe celestial qd she
Of whiche þe grete Euangeliste seynt Iohn
In pathmos wrete whiche saith þtat they goon
By fore þe lambe and syng a song full newe
Þat neuꝰere flesshly women they knewe
This pore widewe waites all þis nyght
After þis litel childe but he yet comes nought
For whiche as sone as it was dayes light
With face pale and drede and besy thought
She hath at scole and elles where hym sought
Tilt finally she gan hym aspye
Þat he was seen last in þe Iurye
With modres pete in herte enclosed
She goth as she were half out of hir mynde
To euꝰery place where she hath supposed
By likelyhode hir Childe for to fynde
And euer on Cristes moder meke and kynde
She cryed and at þe last þus she wrought
She frayned and she prayed petously
To euꝰery Iewe þat duelled in the place
To telle hir if hir Childe wente þer by
They saide nay / but Ihu of his garace
Yaf in hir thought in a litel space
Þat in þat place after hir soone she cried
Where as he was caste in a pytte by side
O grete god þat ꝑperformest thy laude
By mouth of Innocentez loo here thy myght
The gēmme of chastite this Emeraude
And eke of Martirdome þe Rubie bright
There he wtith throte y kutte lay vp right
He Alma Redemptoris gan to syngg
So lowde þat all þe place gan to ryng
Þe Cristen folk þat þurgh þe strete wente
In come for to wundre on this þing
And hastely for þe ꝓprovoste sente
He come a noone with out tarying
And heried Criste þat is heuene kyng
And eke his moder honorur of mankynde
And after þat þe Iewes lete he bynde
Þis Childe with petous lamentacou
Vp taken was syngyng þis song alwaye
And wtith honorur of grete ꝓprocessiou
They caried hym to þe nexte abbey
His moder swownyng by the bere laye
Vnnethes myght þe peple þat was there
This newe Rachel bryng from the bere
With torment and with shamefull deth eche one
Þis ꝓprovoste dooth these Iewes for to sterve
That of this murdre wiste and þat a noone
He nolde non suche cursednesse obserue
Euel shall thaue þat euel wole deserue
Therfore wtith wilde hors h dede hem drawe
And after þat he heng hem by the Mawe
Vpon þe bere ay lithe þis Innocente
By fore þe high autier while þe masse laste
And after þat þe Abbot with þe Couente
Spedde hym to berye hym full faste
And whanne þe holy water he on hym caste
Yet spake þis Childe whan spreyned was þe water
And sang O alma Redemptoris mater
This Abbot whiche was an holy man
As Munkes ben or elles aught for to be
This yong Childe to coniure he by gan
And seid O dere Childe I halse the
In þe vertue of þe holy Trinite
Telle me what is the cause þe for to syng
Sith þat thy throte is kutte at my semyng
My throte is kutte vn to my Nekke boon
Saide þis Childe and as by weye of kynde
I shuld haue be deed ya long tyme a goon
But Ihu Criste as ye in bokes fynde
Wole þat his glory laste and be in mynde
And for þe worship of his moder dere
Yet may I syng O Alma loude and clere
This welle of mercy Cristes moder dere swete
I loved all wey after my konnyng
And whan þat I my lyfe shuld lete
To me she come and bad me for to syng
This Antiewne verrely in my deying
As ye haue herde and when þat I had song
Me þought she leide a greyne vnder my tong
Wherfore I syng and syng mote certeyn
In honoure of þat blisfull maide free
Till fro my tong taken is þe greyn
And after þat þus saide she to me
My litel Childe now wole I fetche þe
Whan þat þi greyne is fro thy tong y take
Be nout a gaste I wole the nat forsake
This holy Monke þis Abbot hym mene I
It oute caught and toke a wey þe greyne
And he gaf vp þe gooste full softely
And whanne þe Abbot hath þe wonder seyne
His salte terys strike doun as reyne
And gruf he fele all platte to þe ground
And stille he lay as he hadde ben y bounde
The couente eke lay vp on þe pavymente
Wepyng and heryng Cristes moder dere
And after þat þei rysen and forth þei wente
And toke a weye þis Martir fro the bere
And in a tumbe of marble stones clere
Enclosed they þis litel body swete
There he is now god leve vs for to mete
O yong hugh of lyncoln y slayn also
With Cursed Iewes as it is notable
For it is but a litel while a goo
Praye for vs synfull folke on stable
Þat of his mercy god so mercyable
Vp on vs his grete mercy multiplie
For reuꝰerence of his moder Marie
Here endeth the tale of the prioras
